text:
Doctor it up!  I've made this recipe for over a year and passed it along by request.  It's a definite 5 star, especially for your time invested.  However, you MUST add seasoning.  This recipe gives you the base.  I would rate it 2-3 stars without additions.  My suggestions...substitute 1/2 broth with Cream of Chicken soup.  Rinse your black beans well!  Add cumin and chili powder...don't be shy.  It gives your soup depth.  Add cilantro and garlic powder, if available.  Grab a rotiserie chicken from your grocery.  I wouldn't expect a 5 star recipe to have canned chicken, would you?  Serve with chunked avocados, cheese, a squeeze of lime and whatever else your heart desires.  Good luck!

text:
Two words best describe this soup:  "EXCELLENT and EASY"!  Several reviewers mentioned that soup was "too salty".  I figured out why.  DO NOT use "condensed" chicken broth; I made this mistake myself.  Recipe calls for "chicken broth", which means plain broth (Swanson and some other companies make it in a 14 1/2 ounce can).  I tried making it again using the correct broth; however, I found it (like other reviewers) to be too watery -- tortilla chips at the bottom of the bowl helped to soak it up though.  I made recipe again; however, this time I used only one 14 1/2 ounce can of chicken broth -and- two cans of condensed cream of chicken soup (99% fat free by Campbells--I DID NOT add water).  The soup tasted SUPERB this way!  I discovered that there was no need to add tortilla chips at the bottom of the bowl because soup was a bit creamy, but without being heavy tasting.  I added some shredded cheddar cheese on the top with a dollop of sour cream, and it looked great, too!  (Note:  "Rotel Diced Tomatoes w/Green Chili Peppers" is offered in varying degrees of spicyness.  I used the "milder" version which gave soup a tiny kick without giving a case of indigestion afterwards.)

text:
This recipe is so quick, easy, and cheap...just open the cans and boil. I only spent about $10.00 on ingredients.  My company thought it was really good.  After reading the other reviews, here's what I came up with which was perfect:  I only used one can of chicken broth (not condensed or it will be too salty), I added 2 cans of condensed cream of chicken soup so it wasn't too watery as other reviewers suggested, used a milder version of tomatoes with green chiles (Rotel tomatoes with lime/cilantro work well).  Be sure to rinse the beans and make sure to season with garlic powder, salt, peper, chili powder, and cumin otherwise there won't be much flavor. Many reviewers suggested adding cilantro which I will try next time. Top with sour cream, cheddar cheese and some tortilla chips and it is perfect.  You really can't go wrong with this one.

text:
Ok, I don't exactly follow this recipe but it gave me some great ideas.  I've cooked variations several times now - the ingredients depend on what I have on hand.

Here's a sample of what I've put in at different times - Carrots, dark and white chicken breasts I've browned in butter, allowed to cool, and shredded, canned diced green chile, green chile enchilada sauce, rice, green onions, yellow onion, canned corn, can of kidney beans, minced fresh garlic or garlic powder, red chile powder, the list goes on and on.  

It's quick to prepare - but tastes best when I put it in the slow cooker and let the flavors really infuse for about 6 hours but one time I made it quickly with rice, chicken, green chiles, and canned corn - and sent it with my husband when he was visiting his sick mom.  GET THIS!  She can't stop raving about it!!  She brags about my cooking to everyone now!! This is a miracle recipe!  

Don't worry if you don't have all the ingredients or want to add other stuff - just use what you have and people will love it!!

text:
I have made this recipe so many times and always with rave reviews, which is saying a lot from my picky husband!  As well as others, I use one can of cream of chicken soup in place of the 2 cans of chicken broth and I don't drain the can of diced tomatoes and chiles so it is still "soupy", I also use a can of mexican corn, drained or frozen corn if I have it on hand instead.  I drain and rinse the black beans because I prefer them that way.  While the soup is simmering I heat the oven to 350 and use a pizza wheel to cut flour tortillas in small, thin strips, bake them for a few minutes until crispy and top the soup with those and a dollop of sour cream. This recipe will remain in my kitchen for years to come and there are so many things you can do to change it up.  Thanks for a great recipe!!

text:
I made this recipe twice so far.  The first time I followed the recipe exactly and it was so boring I forgot that I made it until my husband reminded me while I was cooking it the second time.  He wasnt too excited to see me cooking it again.  So the second time I made lots of adjustments and it was AWESOME!! I used a 48oz box of chicken broth, added 1 can of condensed cream of chicken soup.  I used a rotesserie chicken chopped up. I stuck with the same on corn, rinsed my black beans, and added the drained can of rotel. I added 1 tsp of cumin, 1 tsp of garlic powder, and 2 tsp of chili powder.  It was spicy.. but it seemed to calm down after I added a dollop of sour cream, handful of cheese and some crushed up blue tortilla chips to each bowl.  This recipe must be adjusted to make it awesome.

text:
I used one can of chicken broth and one can of condensed cream of chicken (with 1 can of water). It gave the soup a nice thick consistency. You may want to blend the broth and cream of chicken before adding the other ingredients. The soup's flavor was great, especially the next day. The undrained black beans contributed an unattractive greyish color but I personally love black beans and appreciated them here, as well as the corn (which I don't usually like in recipes). They both added a nice texture. Would have added cumin, etc. but my can of tomatoes + chiles happened to have plenty of seasoning already in it.

text:
I'm glad I gave this recipe a shot. I changed it a little by cutting up a chicken breast in place of the chunk chicken, replacing one of the cans of chicken broth with cream of chicken soup, and adding 1 tsp. cumin. I also drained the beans and corn first to keep it from getting too watery. The result was surprisingly flavorful and filling. The best part was that I didn't need to make a trip to the store for the ingredients, and it took less than 20 minutes. My wife and I have added this to our list of favorites!

text:
Followed other tips and did 1 can broth, 1 can cream of chicken, turned out much richer and heartier this way.  Use fresh chicken(buy a pre-cooked rotisserie and shredding it taste so much better, fresher and gives more of a homemade taste.  And rinse the beans before adding or else it will turn the broth a dark, unappealing color.  Add fresh, chopped cilantro right before serving with some toasted tortilla strip (or can use crushed tortilla chips in a pinch).  I also used frozen corn the 3rd time and was better!  Good base, and with a few additions, turns out restaurant style soup.

Like others, I have made some minor changes:  I use a store-bought rotisserie chicken, 1 can reduced fat cream of chicken and one can broth, 1/2 bag frozen corn, 1 can kidney beans and 1 can  black beans (well rinsed and boiled to get rid of the xs gas), chili ready or jalapeno tomatoes with juice,  1 can of green chiles, some white onions, 1/2 packet of taco seasoning and your choice of toppings...healthy as you make it...THANKS TERRYN for a truly great, easy, healthy, classic recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a great base to work with -- I don't think you can mess it up!  

Go with fresh chicken breast if you can and boil it in the broth as the first step.  I have also used store bought rotisserie chicken, even left over turkey.  You can also use bouillon when no broth on hand.  

My tips: 
1. Add any fresh veggies you have on hand such as carrots, onion, bell pepper, mushrooms and it will taste completely homemade. 
2. Any canned beans work but rinse them off first.
3.  To thicken the soup & give a nice flavor, put about 3 corn tortillas or a couple of hand fulls of corn chips in the food processor, then add the corn "flour" to the soup and simmer a few minutes..it will add a nice complexity and taste even BETTER the next day.

Add or leave out what you want to make this recipe low fat, low carb, vegetarian...it would even be great with left over seafood...mmm!  (To be fair, I must note that I'm prejudiced against can chicken.)

I used perdue shortcuts southwest seasoned chicken pieces vs. the canned chicken, and added 2 tbsp. of chopped FRESH cilantro (ya can't beat it) and a minced clove of garlic.  It was soooo tasty. text:
I've been making this recipe for awhile now and never changed a thing.. simply because it is soooo quick, easy and tasty the way it is. I admit, I would prefer it with fresh chicken and I will do that if we ever have any left over! But as far as the rest of the recipe, I kept it the way it was.. I use Rotel tomatoes w/ green chilies so I monitor the heat and I don't rinse or drain any of the cans. I think the juice from the black beans and corn adds to the flavor. The ingredients are things I buy and just keep on hand. When we feel the urge for this soup, there's no running to the store or waiting all day for the flavors to marry. I sometimes garnish the soup with avocados and sour cream and serve with tortilla chips/strips.  What's not to love about this?  Thank you so much for sharing this wonderful recipe.  BTW, we all know by reading the ingredients that this isn't supposed to be worthy of the Food Network, so don't even try to judge it in that category.  But if you want something tasty and quick.. this is for you.  TRY IT THE WAY IT READS FIRST.. I don't find the need to add the cream of chicken soup; I think it would alter the taste far too much.

Used suggestions found in other reviews: substituted 2 cans (undiluted) Cream of Chicken soup for one of the cans of broth; Rotel brand "Mexican Festival" diced tomatoes (with lime juice & cilantro); S&W brand "Caribbean" Black Beans (with peppers, chilis, onion & lime juice; and hand-shredded grocery store roasted chicken.  Garnished with sour cream, cubed avocado and chopped fresh cilantro.
It was "Oh My God!" good.  My 10 yr-old daughter had two bowls after having dinner at a friend's house (and then again for breakfast this morning!).  Her picky, picky, picky, 13 yr-old sister (who doesn't tolerate spices well) even had seconds - despite being sick with a fever!  
Astonishingly quick and easy.  I already bought supplies for two more batches to keep on hand.  I'm going to go reheat the rest of the leftovers right now, these are my kind of flavors!

text:
This is, hands down, one of our favorite, go-to recipes. We frequently use a rotisserie chicken and its broth instead of canned chicken.  As it simmers, we'll add Southwestern Chipotle seasoning.  The kids know when they come over and visit, we always have a big dutch kettle full of soup on the stove or in the refrigerator.  We've started using raw spinach in the bottom of the bowl, then ladling soup over the spinach.  It's really tasty and healthy. We serve this soup ALL of the time, especially during the cooler months.

text:
My husband and I loved this soup, and he claimed it to be the best tortilla soup he's ever had! I used 4 chicken tenders, flavored them with some Famous Dave's seasoning for a little extra kick, baked and then shredded them. I followed the advise of others and used one can of chicken broth (not condensed) and 2 cans of cream of chicken soup. I rinsed and drained the black beans well to avoid a gray looking soup. I also used the recommended Rotel tomatoes with lime juice and cilantro. I made my own tortilla strips to place on top. We still can't get over how good this was and I will be making it again soon!

text:
This was super delicious, after i added some things. i kinda doubled the recipe. i used 1 can chicken broth to 3 cans cream of chicken soup, 6 boneless skinless chicken breasts cut into chunks, 2 cans of corn, drained, 1 can of rotel w/ green chiles (Hot version) also drained,  i didnt have black beans so i used 1 can of Ranch Style Beans Drained, and rinsed, and I put in one can of Campbells Fiesta Nacho cheese, and one can of Campbell's Cheddar Cheese. Added Salt, Pepper, Garlic Powder, Chili Powder, and Cumin, all to taste. (about 2 -3 tsp of each for me). I let it cook for 8 hours on low in the crock pot and all of the flavors blended amazingly. such an AMAZING recipe:) my father-in-law claims its the best bowl of soup he's ever ate. Thanks so much for sharing, i hope this review comes in useful.

country:
None
text:
I absolutely loved this recipe!  I'm so happy I read the reviews before I made it cause the original recipe did need a little tweaking.  Instead of using 2 cans of chicken broth, I used only one can and then a can of Cream of Chicken (along with only half a can of water). Make sure you drain and wash the black beans! The beans will make the soup watery and add an unattractive black color.  Also, I would definitely recommend adding cilantro!  It gives it that added bit of flavor.  You'll also need to add some salt, pepper, cumin, garlic powder, and cayenne pepper (adds a little heat).  I also added brown rice because the Mexican restaurant near my house makes it that way.  Cook the rice a little more than halfway then add to the soup.  The rice soaks up the broth and flavors nicely and adds good body to the soup!

Very easy, tastes good! Great easy recipe!!

text:
QUICK, EASY, DELICIOUS!!! I've made it for years and my kiddos still ask for it.  I do have a few additional ingredients.  1 can Cream Style Corn, 1 chopped onion and 2-3-4 chopped garlic cloves (we love the garlic in it).  Usually I boil a package of boneless, skinless chicken thighs and shred them.  I like that better than canned chicken and it leaves me the broth to thin with.  What's really nice about this is you can make a thick hearty stew like soup, or a thinner soup.  Either way its delicious!!!

text:
Oh my goodness this was SO good on this cold night!  I changed it only a little based on some reviews I read here...this is what I did:  First I combined the 2 cans of chicken broth with 1 can of cream of chicken soup - perfect consistency!  Rinsed the black beans, drained the corn and tomatoes and mixed those 3 together with some seasonings (fresh ground black pepper, garlic and cumin), then I added this mixture to the soup.  For the chicken I used about 1/2 a rotisserie chicken from the store (not a big fan of can chicken either) - pulled it apart into bite size pieces and added it to the soup.  Heated it through and dinner was done!  I served it over tortilla chips and topped with white cheese (shredded Queso Quesadilla cheese) and a small dollop of sour cream.  YUM!

text:
Reduce chicken broth to 1 (14.5 oz) can.  Add 1 can Cream of Chicken soup (reduced fat or fat free).
Drain tomoatoes and black beans (the color is much better if you do this and there is already plenty of liquid).  Use 1 package of Perdue Shortcuts Southwest seasoned chicken cut into bite size pieces.  Add 1 tsp. ground Cumin.  This is wonderful for a last minute dinner.

userID:
7806595
Display Name:
gm90369
isPro:

1
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/919026.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This tortilla soup recipe is much better if you add some minced white onion, minced garlic, chopped cilantro. Season the soup with chili powder, some garlic salt and a little seasoned salt to taste. You can thicken the soup by adding in a 1/4 cup cold water with a tablespoon wondra. Once it begins to boil remove the following ingredients from the pan and place into a separate frying pan with a little canola oil: cooked shredded chicken, onion, garlic, chopped cilantro, corn, black beans saute them together for about 5 minutes in medium heat in a little canola oil, sprinkle them with chili powder and garlic salt to add more flavor and color. Then when you are serving the soup into individual bowls, spoon in the broth first & then your sauted chicken, corn, black beans, onions, and cilantro on top. You will find this makes the soup amazing, especially if you add some crunchy corn tortilla strips, shredded mexican cheese, and a dollop of sour cream. Enjoy!

text:
Good, BUT . . . I agree with practically all the other reviewers: substitute one can of Cream of Chicken soup for one of the cans of (reduced-sodium) chicken broth. Also its much better if you boil & dice 2 chicken breasts; but if you're really in a time pinch, use TWO cans of chicken chunks.  I prefer TWO cans of diced tomatoes with zesty green chiles (UNdrained) and DON'T FORGET to rinse & drain the black beans!  I prefer to use a bag of frozen corn, rather than canned corn. And lastly, Spice it up, baby!  Add at least a teaspoon of cumin & a  tablespoon of chili powder and top it with some chopped fresh cilantro, sour cream & grated cheese!  Yum, than Terryn for a good starter-base recipe!

country:
None
text:
Too salty prepared as written. However, it is very easy to make changes that your blood pressure will appreciate. Cook chicken breast or thighs in water which you will use as a broth replacement. Use frozen corn. Use canned black or pinto beans, drained and rinsed well. Add two chopped Roma tomatoes and a few teaspoons of finely chopped poblano or anaheim green chile. The only sodium in this modified recipe will come from the canned beans and it will be reduced by about 50% by rinsing well. I add some sodium free taco seasoning that I buy from a bulk foods supplier. And a little fresh minced garlic and a wedge of lime will finish this nicely. It is very flavorful using these fresh ingredients. Happy heart health!

This is very tasty as is, I made it as written the first time.  This time, as per suggestions, I made it in the slow cooker with two chicken breasts. (1 hour on high, 2 on low, removed and shredded chicken then returned it and cooked for 2 hours more on low. Note to self: Added a tsp of cumin, 1/2 tsp of chili powder and a can of low sodium cream of chicken as per other suggestions and 2 Tbsp of goya cilantro base, which all together made it absolutely amazing!!  Be sure to use low sodium broth, 2 cans is equal to most of a carton.  Fat free sour cream works well with this.

text:
I followed the advice of others and used the following: 1 can Rotel tomatoes with Lime & Cilantro, 1 can yellow corn, 1 can chicken broth, 2 cans condensed cream of chicken soup, 1 can (drained and rinsed) black beans, and 1 12.5 oz can chunk chicken.  Because I was short on time, I just threw it all in the crock pot and let it go.  I didn't add anything else to it.  We served it with toasted tortilla strips, cheddar cheese and a dollup of sour cream, as recommended by SPRING1ONU.  It was a hit with our family of 6.  I wish I had doubled it, because some wanted seconds, and it was all gone.  Also, if I have more time, I might use a rotisserie chicken the next time, but this recipe fit the bill perfectly for us, especially on a chilly, rainy evening.

text:
Wow!  This soup is awesome with some added spices.  I have made this twice.  The first time I followed the recipe and it definitely needed spice and was too watery.  Big time.  I made it a second time and it came out perfect with these changes.  Rinse the black beans well, one can cream of chicken soup, two cans swansons broth,  one can of rotel with green chiles.  I did not drain the can and it was spicy.  If you don't want the spice, definitely drain it.  I also added about 1T cummin and 1T chili powder.  I kid you not, the best tortilla soup I have ever had, and my family agrees.  Every single one of them.  My only request from my family is to double it!

I'm stuck in my home due to mother nature and didn't have much to work with this evening.  I did have everything in my pantry for this soup except the canned chicken.  Sooo, I diced up some chicken tenders and sauteed them with red bell pepper.  After I drained the veggies, I added them to the pot along with some onion powder, garlic powder and salt.  Even after some seasonings..it still tasted like it was missing something.  I sprinkled some Romano cheese on top of my serving..(big mistake).  It made my bowl stink!!  Even hubby, who was sitting in the living room asked me "What's that smell"?   Eventually, after the stinky cheese melted, the soup tasted a little better.  Might make this again when my pantry is running on empty.

None
text:
This was very good. I didn't have canned chicken so instead I put 3 frozen chicken breasts in a pot covered them with 6 cups water and let them cook. When they were done I took them out to cool and added all the rest of the ingredients (boullion instead of broth since I had some nice flavored water in the pot already), plus cumin, chili powder and I also cooked up some onion and garlic as had been suggested. I also added a can of kidney beans as well as the black beans. When the chicken was cooled my son and I shredded it together and put it into the pot. Just before I served the soup I cut a tortilla into 1/2 inch strips with a pizza cutter and put them in a pan with oil and cooked them quickly, took them out onto a paper towel and sprinkled them with garlic/herb seasoning. After I dished the soup into a bowl I took a few cooked tortilla strips and stood them up in the bowl of soup, leaning on each other (looked kind of like a tee-pee). Made for a nice presentation and they were yummy. I'm not much of a soup person (my husband is) but I must say that this was pretty tasty and I'll definitely make it again. Who'd have thought that homemade soup could be so easy?!?

text:
Want to know what this soup is missing? At the last 5 minutes of warming up this soup, add one corn tortilla broken up into pieces, and continue simmering soup until hot. The corn tortilla will break up and give the soup an AUTHENTIC tortilla soup flavor. All the other ingredients are great (substitute the canned chicken for freshly poached and shredded chicken when you feel like cooking), plus whatever other stuff you like. A good foundation recipe for tortilla soup!

text:
This was great (and cheap, which is my favorite part). I cut up raw chicken tenderloins, put them in a crockpot, poured two tablespoons of melted butter over it, seasoned with cumin, chili powder, and garlic powder, set the crockpot on low and let it cook for about 5 and a half hours. Took the lid off, broke up the chicken pieces and poured the rest of the ingredients in, only I used a can of cream of chicken soup in place of one of the broth cans, and I rinsed the beans and corn together in a strainer. I also added more of the spices mentioned above. I used tortilla strips on top (that you can buy on the salad dressing aisle). Wonderful!

text:
I've been making this for several years now. I cook seasoned chicken breasts in the broth and use 1 can cr of chicken soup. Rinse the black beans for a clearer soup. I also add Birdseye southwestern rice & use frozen super sweet corn. Today I actually made it in the oven since we're having a blizzard & I wanted the oven on.Just let it simmer at 250 degrees. I add extra ingredients all the time to make a HUGE batch of this soup. Everyone always loves it. Rotel Cilantro & Lime tomatoes work good in this recipes and you can make it as hot or mild as you like. I never drain the tomatoes. Definitely a recipe I use time after time. Have fun with it & add whatever you want!

Display Name:
Jacey
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good basic recipe, but the great thing about this is that you can add any ingredients and seasonings you want. I'm a huge soup fan and make it quite often. I rarely follow a recipe.  To me how the chicken is seasoned is important, if you don't have a Rotisserie chicken, I'd cook in a skillet, in a little oil, with garlic/onion powder, then make sure it has a nice browned coloring. 
I add cumin, garlic powder, pepper, chili powder, a touch of cayenne or red pepper flakes if making for adults only. Try it with white beans - you will love it! I don't drain them, then they add to the thickness. I add a few tortilla strips to the soup itself at the very end, then have some out for people to add themselves. Top w/Monterey Jack cheese, a little sour cream, fresh avocado and it's a great meal!    Just taste as you're cooking and add what is needed.

text:
I loved this recipe! I did make adjustments as suggested in other reviews. I used a can of plain Swanson's chicken broth (not condensed) and one can of Cream of Chicken soup. I also added the Ro-tel that had lime and cilantro instead of the type that uses green chilies. I didn't have chicken on-hand and am a bit creeped out by canned chicken, so I substituted with a can of chickpeas. I drained and rinsed both the black beans and chickpeas. I added whole kernel corn, undrained, as suggested. I then added a bunch of cumin, garlic pepper, garlic powder -- basically, I just threw spices in. It really added a depth to the soup. Next time, I'll probably add some fresh onion. The possibilities are endless and it's really great to make a tasty meal that's on a budget and can be taken for lunches to the office for several days in a row.

text:
This was really good!  Like some other users, I made a few slight changes.  I sauteed off a medium onion and a tablespoon of garlic.  I cooked about 1 and 1/4 lb of thin sliced chicken breast in the oven, instead of canned.  I used about 4 cups of low sodium chicken broth, and I used chipotle seasoned tomatoes.  I also added about 2 teaspoons of cumin and 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper.  Everyone loved it, I'll definitely make this again!  The whole shebang took about an hour.  Oh, and I also made some white rice on the side to add in!!  I plan on using leftover turkey the next time I make it....yum!

userID:
6707088
Display Name:
chaplainesque
isPro:
False
followersCount:
8
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
25
favoritesCount:
172
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The beauty of this recipe is that you can put it together in five minutes or less, if you have a good can-opener!  However, my family won't eat it unless I freshen it up a bit.  You can do this while the bulk of the ingredients are already in the pot on the stove.  It takes very litte time to strip an ear or two of corn - and fresh does taste better than canned.  If you have some left-over chicken roasted or baked, or even poached, it will most certainly taste better than canned.  If you happen to have frozen your very own chicken stock or broth and are generous enought to use it, you'll be in gourmet territory.  Just substitute any or all of these fresh elements for the canned ones while the pot is already simmering.  If there's time, you could even flash-fry a cut-up skinless, boneless chicken breast and dump it in.  Whether or not you have made thse "improvements", do add some garlic squeezed in your garlic press, some lemon or lime juice if you have either of these fruits lying around (don't bother with the b ottled kind), and chop a handful of parsley or cilantro and /or scallions if available.  Spice it up with fresh chilis or a pinch or two of cayenne pepper if your crowd likes it. Now - you've got a soup no one could sneeze at, and you got there easily, knowing that you could do it all with cans if you wanted to!Thanks to Terryn for helping me con myself into cooking when I was really too tired!!

Amazing recipe!  With a few tweaks, the soup tasted just like the expensive version they make at a local restaurant!  I omitted the chile peppers, rinsed the black beans in a colander with cold water, and like other reviewers said, I added two regular cans of condensed cream of chicken soup. text:
Could not be more simple.  This was my second time making this soup, the first time I drained but didn't rinse the beans and it turned the soup an ugly grey color...still delicious, just ugly.  This time I rinsed them really well.  I also made a cup of white rice and put that in the soup as well, it really helped thicken it without having to use a cream soup like other reviewers did.  As for seasoning, I added a splash of lemon juice, a lot of garlic powder, chili powder, cumin, paprika, salt, pepper, and a dash of red pepper flakes.  I put mozzerella and a tortilla chip crumbled on top.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I took a slightly modified version of this to a potluck at church tonight, and it was a big hit.  My husband and I really loved it, too. I loved how EASY it was to make!

I was uncertain about using canned chicken, so I followed the advice of one of the reviewers and bought a rotisserie chicken in Walmart's deli. 

To make a large pot, I put in 3 cans drained corn, 3 cans Rotel (2 regular, and 1 mild), and 3 cans rinsed & drained black beans. I added about half of a large chicken. I added 2 cans of Cream of Chicken, about 30 oz each, and 2 cartons of chicken broth, also about 30 oz each.

The only seasoning I added was some Cumin, and I just shook it in there, stirring and tasting 'til it was right (maybe 1 TBSP or so). 

It tasted wonderful. We served it over Mission Tortilla Strips (chips), with a sprinkling of grated cheddar cheese, and a dollop of sour cream. I will be making this recipe ALOT. Thanks to who shared it!

text:
I found this recipe on here over 5 years ago & have used it regularly ever since . I figured it was about time I reviewed it ! It's wonderful just as it is but I do add a spoonful or 2 of taco seasoning , use half broth & half cream of chicken & whatever form of Rotel tomatoes & chilis I have on hand (usually a combination of tomatoes & jalapenos & tomatoes with lime and cilantro). I buy white shredded chicken in 3lb. cans , use part of it & freeze the rest (getting @ least 3 meals /can ) Skip the chips & sour cream & you have a nutritious diet friendly hot lunch !

text:
This is one of the best soup recipes EVER!  I have taken this to potlucks, church soup suppers and family dinners and every time I make it people ask for the recipe. I do make it with the cream of chicken soup as many other people suggested as it seemed too "watered down" with just the broth.  I also use frozen corn in place of the canned corn, boiled chicken breasts in place of canned chicken and I add chili powder and cumin to taste.  This soup is even better then next day after the flavors have really blended.

text:
I made this tonight for my family and doubled the recipe.  It was awesome, though I did alter it a bit.  I first sauteed half an onion in a little olive oil, then added 2 cans of chicken broth, and a can of cream of mushroom and a can of cream of chicken.  I also added two cans of water, and some cumin and black pepper.  I then added the Rotel and frozen corn and black beans.  I didn't use canned chicken (yuck), but used shredded chicken from a rotisserie roast.  It came out marvelous and my family loved it with sour cream and crushed tortilla chips.  Thanks for a great recipe :)

text:
I have had so much fun with this recipe! My version has changes it a bit. I do not drain the corn, but I do rinse & drain the black beans, I also add a can of undrained great northern beans. I like to use 1 can of Campbell's Select Mexican Chicken Tortilla Soup instead of the 2 broth and my best results were using 5-6 chopped breaded Tysons Buffalo style chicken tenders (I have also using the meat from leftover buffalo wings)instead of the canned chicken. I bring all ingredients to a boil, cover and let stand until just warm. Then I blend partially with an immersable stick blender to thicken and improve texture. No one knows what's in it, but they are nuts for it!

Display Name:

text:
This was a pretty good soup with some alterations, due to having kids..... I doubled the recipe, but used 1 can of broth, and 1 can cream of chicken w/ 1 can of water. I used 1 can regular corn and 1 can cream style corn. I used 1 can of Ro-Tel MILD tomatoes and 1 can regular tomatoes. I used 2 cans of black beans, but I did rinse them well prior to adding them (canned black beans if not rinsed will give any dish an ill looking color.). I used two cooked and cubed chicken breasts, seasoned with garlic powder and black pepper. I threw this all in my crockpot, cooked on low for about 6 hours. I served it with shredded cheese and dollops of sour cream.

text:
This was fabulous! Everyone enjoyed it so much that...we all took it the next day for lunch.  I did make a few changes though. Most of the soups such as this that I have had in the past have had a tomato base...more than just the diced tomato's so...I added about a half a cup of pureed tomato's after I added everything else and also about a tablespoon or so of sugar just to sweeten it up a bit. Oh...and I also...at the advice of others...used one less can of chicken stock and used a can of cream of chicken soup in place of it. I used chicken tenders that I cut up and sprinkled a touch of cayenne and chili power on before I cooked them. Can't say that I would ever use canned chicken. I also added additional cayenne and crushed red peppper flakes to it to give it an extra kick and it was just perfect! I will be making this one....again and again. Thank you for another winning recipe!

I normally steer away from recipes calling for  several canned items but ... THIS WAS SUPER.  Inspired by some of the other reviews, I substituted one of the cans of broth with Healthy Request cream of chicken soup, used extra hot Rotel tomatoes with chilies, a few black olives with jalapenos and chunked freshly cooked chicken breast.  I broke up some tortilla chips in the bottom of the bowl and to the top, when serving, I added green onion, sour cream and a little cubed avocado.  Made some fresh cornbread on the side.  We loved it and will make it over and over again.  Warning: our version is very spicy.

I did use what other reviewers posted to add to this base recipe and it turned out delicious!  I was surprised by all the flavors.  This is what I did, I used a can of chicken broth, 2 cans of cream of chicken soup, I rinsed my black beans, I usually don't care for canned chicken but since I had some I used it, I added cumin, chili powder, garlic powder, and cilantro.  As another reviewer posted I cut up two tortillas and baked at 350 for a few minutes.  I topped it with baked tortillas, cheese, sour cream, and chives.  Thank you all for the reviews and thanks for posting this recipe. Quick, easy, and delicious!

text:
I love this recipe. It's simple and my son loves it. My co-workers loved this. I made this over Thanksgiving with leftover turkey, it was great. I used the reviews from the other raters and I highly recommend you take their suggestions. 1 can of cream of chicken, 1tsp cumin, 1 tsp garlic powder, 2 tsp of chili powder, and I use the rotisserie chicken you buy at Walmart for less than $5 and cut up 2 cups, perfectly seasoned, and already hot and ready. We are talking 10-15 min. tops and dinner or lunch is ready.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did a few things to this already great recipe.  It is on my file as 8-can chicken tortilla soup.  I used 2 cans chicken broth, 2 cans condensed cream of chicken soup (not low fat), 2 cans of Rotel tomatoes and green chiles (mild), 1 can of drained corn, and 1 can of rinsed and drained black beans.  I grilled 2 chicken breasts seasoned with salt, pepper, seasoning salt, and a spicy steak seasoning mix, and shredded them into the soup. I seasoned soup with salt, black pepper, red pepper flakes, ground cumin, garlic powder, onion powder, and 2 envelopes sazon seasoning.  This really helps to give flavor and color. Thanks for a real keeper.

text:
I had a can of chicken and didn't know what to do with it. We don't really like canned chicken in most things. But this did turn out really good. I admit I added a couple of extra cans of what I had - an extra can of diced tomatoes w/chiles, a can of cream of chicken soup - and I didn't drain the tomatoes because I typically only have buillon on hand, not canned broth, so I always have to add water to these recipes. ANYWAY. It was really surprisingly good. Spicier than I thought thanks to the tomatoes with chiles. I will make this again but I think the recipe doesn't provide enough liquid as written. Oh also I made this in a small slow cooker, just leaving it on for a few hours to let everything blend without having to worry about stirring. So it's really good if you have little time to prepare.

Display Name:
Ruth Carman-Esser

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6429196.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
2015 update: Still 5 stars! I LOVE THIS RECIPE. I've been making this for several years now, probably more than 200 batches.  It is the absolutely best chicken soup recipe I have.  I ALWAYS make sure I have the ingredients for this on hand.  When I don't feel well, it is so easy to throw together.  Today, I changed it up a little...again. Used the 6 cans as listed, used hominy corn. Skipped the taco seasoning and added 4 cloves of garlic, sliced.  Great for fending off a cold.  Last time, I added sauteed onions, mushrooms and garlic, left out the Rotel and added 4 oz HOT jalapenos and 1 can Fire Roasted Diced tomatoes. I also substituted a can of whole white hominy for the whole corn.  Good thing I tasted before adding taco seasoning - it didn't need any after those jalapenos went in!  By the way, instead of using canned chicken, I make this with leftover turkey after the holidays. Now, back to your regularly scheduled program... 
I'll admit it - I keep canned chicken in my pantry for emergencies.  But this is the ONLY recipe I've ever found that makes canned chicken edible.  More than that, with spicy tomatoes and peppers, and a little homemade taco seasoning, it's pretty good. (Drain the chicken, definitely!) Please note that as written, this recipe is naturally gluten-free (WooHooooo!)  Next time, I plan to substitute refried beans for the black beans, for the flavor and the thickening effect.  I served it with tortilla chips, sour cream and shredded Cheddar, with oranges

text:
As it reads I gave it 3 stars. I doubled the recipe to make 12 servings. It's a great starting point. After tasting and it was too bland I added about 4 cups of chicken stock made from boiling a roasted chicken. Then I added about 2 tablespoons of prepared taco seasoning. Simmered for 20 minutes and served with 2% shredded Mexican cheese and Fritos on top. Was much much more flavorful. We loved it and I have several more meals left of it ;)

text:
An EXCELLENT soup!  My family LOVED it!  As other reviews have said, I did tweak it a bit.  Instead of 2 chicken broths, I did 1 cream of chicken soup and 1 chicken broth - both of them fat free.  I also shredded up some chicken I grilled instead of canned chicken.  Finally, I also added seasonings - cilantro, green onions, cumin, chili powder, garlic powder, and salt and pepper!  YUM!  Top it off with a dollop of light sour cream and some cheese along with some crunched up tortilla chips and you have a masterpiece!

text:
One word = DELISH!
For a heartier, thicker soup... you can also add one (1) 10oz. can of cream of chicken and 1/2 cup of prepared/cooked rice. Feel free to use any kind of rice you'd like (i.e. plain white rice, yellow rice or even chicken flavored Rice A Roni). The rice definitely adds great texture and makes the soup more filling! Sprinkled with some Mexican shredded cheese and garnished with a few blue corn tortilla chips... and you've got yourself one hearty Mexican inspired meal!

Allison

city:

country:

text:
I made some changes based on the reviews, and I'm giving it 5 stars because of the way it turned out.  I watch what I eat and only eat organic, so here is what I added to be specific.  First off, I wanted to use quality SHREDDED chicken, so it's easy when you can use the crock pot.  I used two organic and free-range breasts, and put them in the crock pot for 3.5 hours in one can of organic cream of chicken soup, 15 ounces of chicken broth (yes, organic), 1.5 tsp of cumin, 1/2 tsp of chili powder, 1 tsp of garlic, 1 tsp. ground black pepper and 1/2 tsp kosher salt.  After the chicken fell apart (3.5 hours), I added the cans of veggies, and every can I added was of the organic variety.  Find whatever you can.  I also used organic cheese at the end as a garnish in addition to an organic lime to juice over the top.  In my bowl, I ate just the soup with no cheese or tortilla chips, but with my partner (who can't seem to gain weight no matter what he does) I added the cheese and crushed tortillas.  I figured this recipe out to be LESS than 200 calories per serving if you do not add cheese or tortilla chips and I didn't miss them at all.  It's a little spicy this way, but very authentic tasting!  In the future, I might put a dollop of sour cream on top of my partner's soup - he could use the fat, and I'm sure it would taste good, too.

text:
My version! Very yummy.
1 (15 ounce) can whole kernel corn, drained 
1 (14.5 ounce) cans chicken broth 
1 (15 ounce) can black beans (rinsed well)
1 (10 ounce) can diced tomatoes with green chile peppers, drained 
2 cans of Cream of Chicken soup
2 cooked chicken breast (shredded)
2 tsp. Cumin spice
2 tsp. Garlic Powder
2 tsp. Chili Powder

text:
My husband and I both loved this recipe. It will definitely become a part of our regular menu. I made a few modifications: used baked chicken instead of canned, added 1/2 packet of taco seasoning, and added 1 tablespoon of cornstarch to thicken the broth. It was fabulous. I also took the suggestions that others added to top with tortilla chips and cheese. I would highly recommend this, especially for those looking for a quick and filling meal. When making this recipe the third time, I decided to add a can of fat free refried beans to thicken the soup, and it was perfect. It gave the soup a great texture.

text:
Excellent soup.  As recommended by ohers, instead of using 2 cans of broth I used two cans of Campbells Select Mexican tortilla soup.  Also used half of a rotisserie chicken instead of the canned chicken.  Be sure to drain and rince the black beans before adding to avoid having your soup turn grey!  I served the soup using the Baked Dostito Chips trying to keep the fat grams down.  I served this to my sister inlaw who wanted the recipe.  She made a batch, took some to work and shared some with a co-worker who also loved it and asked for the recipe.  The co-worker went home and made it for her husband, who just loved it and asked fora second bowl.  Definately a keeper.  If you are thinking about making this recipe, don't hesitate - just do it!

text:
I have made this several times and can't thank you enough for this FABULOUS recipe!  I use chicken breast, sub 1 can of low fat cream of chicken for 1 can of broth, use only 1/2 bag of frozen corn, add some finely chopped onions, a can of kidney beans in addition to the black (for color), 2 cans of chili-tomatoes with the juice and the 1/2 packet of taco seasoning...it's not only delicious, but also keeps it healthy! It's so tasty, that we actually skip the tortilla chips! Thanks again for a great recipe!!!

I've modified it a little...1 can chicken (if I don't have time to boil chicken), 2 cans chicken broth, I puree the 1 can of diced tomatoes, 1 can black beans, 1 can corn, and I add one can of enchilada sauce. text:
This received five stars in my family. I used 2 cans of broth but with 2 cans of cream of chicken soup. Otherwise it would not have fed our family of three. I left out the beans as they are not big with us and used frozen corn which tasted fine. Also used a can of Rotel suggested by others which I think gave it plenty of kick. I did add some grated Mexican blend cheese on top and also tried it with a dollop of sour cream on top. Both were great and the sour cream even cuts the bite nicely.  The only other thing is next time I'll cut out the tortilla chips entirely. I don't think they're needed. Thanks for an easy and delicious recipe.

I like this recipe a lot and I used many of the reviewer recommendations. text:
I almost didn't try this recipe because I like to make things from scratch. So here's what I used following the general guidelines of the original recipe:
1 can whole kernel corn, drained. 1 can of pinto beans since my husband doesn't like black beans. 2 cups of homemade (organic) chicken broth. Prebaked, diced chicken breasts which I had in my freezer. A can of Roitel diced tomatoes with chili peppers. 
Before serving I sprinkled a generous amount of Louisiana hot sauce on top, since my husband and I both like things spicy, plus some cheddar cheese. It was awsome! Best soup I ever made.
Thanks for the inspiration Terryn!

text:
I gave this an extra star because it's so easy.  Canned chicken doesn't excite me, so I replaced it with a second can of black beans.  I took another reviewer's advice and added 1/2 packet of taco seasoning mix.  I also replace one can of chicken broth with 1 can of condensed cream of chicken soup to make things thicker and creamier.  I don't use the tomatoes with chile peppers because I don't like hot food - I have no problem with it being bland without them.  Oh, always rinse your beans - it helps keep the bean "after effect" down to a minimum.

text:
Absolutely you have to doctor this recipe, but it is an amazing base recipe to make something your own and great.
I wanted to try and keep mine as natural as possible so I skipped the cream of soup tips.  I was lucky enough to find, at my local grocer, Swanson's Mexican Tortilla flavor infused broth and I think that is what helped my soup the most.  I still added lots of fresh garlic because I love garlic, but other then that I kept everything else the same.  I added the whole 32oz box of the broth and it wasn't to "soupy" for me.  Also I added red pepper flakes and then topped it with plain yogurt and blue tortilla chips to cool it down.  This has probably been one of my favorite things I've made and I've tried a lot off of this site.
So give it a try, make it your own and enjoy!
p.s. I simmered my for about an hour because I had the time.

I gave this recipe a 4 star instead of a 5 star due to changing it just a little. I didn't follow this to the 'T'. First I had to add some spice. I added, per my taste, chilli powder and oregano. I also added some fat free sour cream, tortilla chips and green onions to the top of the soup. 
After the small changes I can say this soup will be on the table a few times during the month. The cost is very low and everyone in the family LOVED it. Double WIN!

userID:

Display Name:
lswanson3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great BASE recipe for chicken tortilla soup!! I did this recipe in my crock pot with a few tweaks. I swapped canned chicken for fresh strips of chicken breast. B/c I didn't want to wait for raw chicken to cook in the crock pot, I cooked the chicken in a frying pan for 2 mins. on each side. Add partially cooked chicken to crock pot with 1 Cup of Chicken Broth and let cook on High for 1.5-2 hours. Shred chicken and add the drained corn, drained & RINSED black beans, diced tomatoes (not drained) & the rest of the can of chicken broth plus the second can from the original recipe. ADDITIONS: I added two cans of 10.5 oz condensed cream of chicken to add thickness. And for flavoring I added garlic powder, salt, pepper, and LOTS of chili powder. Top with a dollop of sour cream if you wish and some left over flour tortillas cut into strips and baked. I also garnished with a bit of shredded cheese.

This is a great little recipe to play with and have around for those days when you just need something w/o a big fuss ! 
Thanks to the originator - we did love it !

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good basic recipe to build upon either with chicken or vegetarian style.  The recipe as is definetly needs some kick from adding extra spices. Many other of the reviewers complained of too much salt as well.  To eliminate some of the salt content, I use canned beans and corn with no added salt and rinsed each well. I also simmered two bone chicken breasts with a 1/4 tsp salt and a few pepper corns, when done removed bones and shredded.  I then used the broth from the chicken breast in the soup and then added the veggies.  Instead of two cans of cream of chicken soup, recommended by others I used only about 1/4 cup of red enchilada sauce, to add some additional kick to the additional spices.  I too then followed the recipe by adding baked tortilla chips, homemade at the bottom of the bowel.

text:
I made this soup exactly to the recipe except that I added cooked frozen spinach instead of the corn (we didn't have any).  Even if we had corn, I would definitely add the spinach in again next time.  Even with mild tomatoes and chilis, it is still pretty spicy for us, so I served the kids' portions on top of rice and sprinkled cheese on top.  All three said they "love" it.  Rather than rice, I crushed tortilla chips on top of mine and that made it outstanding.

None
text:
I got a similar recipe from Weight Watchers in 2001, and I've been making it since then, and it's always well received. I like it because it's all pantry items and makes a large batch, sometimes impromptu. I make it w/2 cans of chicken, a jar of salsa, a carton of low sodium chicken broth, a can of black beans (rinsed and drained), and a can of low fat refried beans. Delicious and easy, but a bit high in salt, and it's all in cans, so not optimum nutrition, but high marks for ease, expense, and quantity. I always keep a stash of these ingredients on hand if I unexpectedly need/want to feed extra people.

This is a solid, fast and tasty soup recipe.  I enjoyed it as is and I tried it another time with a few revisions.  I did not have diced tomatos and chiles so I subsitituted a can of Campbells Tomato soup and a packet of taco seasoning.  I combined the soup, chicken broth and taco seasoning first, brought them to boil and then simmered for 5 minutes before adding the corn, chicken and black beans.  Nice flavor!

Made this tonight....and it was SOOOOOO worth it!  YUMMY!!!!  I made a whole chicken last night so wanted to do something different with the "leftover" chicken.  I, like others, used 1 can of cream of chicken soup and 2 cans of chicken broth.  The tomatoes I had didn't have chile peppers, so I chopped up some jalapeno's I had in the freezer. text:
I used what I had on hand which was fresh cooked chicken, a bag of corn, 2 cans of mild rotel, 2 cans of black beans and 2 cans of chicken broth.  My friend is gluten intolerant, so as much as I wanted to add cream of chicken soup, I didn't.  I did add 2 teaspoons of cumin and 1/2 tsp of garlic salt.  Threw it all in the crockpot on low for about 3 hours.  This was excellent!  Not too much broth at all! My whole family and guest loved it!  Couldn't believe how simple and easy!   Definitely will become a staple!

text:
This recipe was a great base...however it needed some punch. I used 1 can corn, 1 can black beans, 1 can navy beans, 1 can tomatoes and chilies (hot), 1/2 can diced tomatoes, 1 14 1/2 ounce can of chicken broth, 1 small can cream of chicken. This added a lot more character but the real kicker was the seasoning! instead of adding a bunch of random stuff, i used a Mccormic white chicken chili packet. just threw it in there, but to keep it from tasting chili like i added some jarred salsa and it freshened it right up. This is absolutely delicious! i served with cheddar cheese, sour cream, and fritos :)

Amazing flavor, and extremely quick and easy to make.  I was a little skeptical about the recipe - I thought that I would be adding some adding some seasonings or extra ingredients to amp up the flavor.  But when I tasted the soup, I was pleasantly surprised to find that I didn't need to add a thing.  Fantstic flavor and color.  I did use fresh chicken, but otherwise remained true to the original recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We went to two stores to get a rotisserie chicken, but both places were out, so I sucked it up and used canned chicken.  It was actually really good with the canned chicken.  This marks the first time I've ever been able to stomach canned chicken.  I actually couldn't stop eating this soup- it was so good.  All of the family loved it, too.  I actually used a quart of canned tomatoes and two cans of diced green chiles instead of the rotel, so that's about 4 times as much rotel as the recipe calls for.  I also drained the beans and corn.  For people who want to thicken this up, masa harina works very well as a thickener and the taste is perfect with this.  We topped with cheddar chese, sour cream, and crushed tortilla chips, but it's really good plain too.

text:
I was pleasantly surprised at how flavorful and spicy the soup turned out. After reading the reviews regarding flavor, I tried a different cooking method. I dumped everything into the crock pot and cooked it on low for a couple of hours. It allowed the flavors to really soak in and develop. No extra spices were needed! I used the Rotel tomatoes with green chiles and lime, Trappey's Black Beans seasoned with olive oil, garlic, and onions and an extra can of chicken. Nothing was drained or rinsed. All of the flavors came out perfectly! Might add rice to it next time.

text:
Delicious! Add these seasonings: Cumin, Chili Powder, & Garlic to taste, as well as salt & pepper!  I tried this and took the advice from the review by SSCHULTE14 and used 1 can chicken broth & 1 can cream of chicken (instead of 2 cans of broth) and added the Cumin, Chili Powder & Garlic Powder seasoning - not being shy with the seasoning as SSCHULTE14 suggested!   Substitutions I made:  No Cilantro, so I used the Lime Juice and Cilantro flavored Rotel.   I used cooked chicken breast in place of canned chicken. Just boil or bake chicken and then shread with a fork.   MY HUSBAND ABSOLUTELY LOVES THIS!!!!!!!  This is a FAVORITE recipe now, and I just discovered it a couple of weeks ago & have already made it 3 times!   You will want to DOUBLE this recipe!

Excellent recipe! The picky husband who thinks  he's too good to eat canned foods never turns down a bowl if this. Gets 5 stars not only for taste, but ease of preparation and versatility. Used fresh chicken with the skin, (didn't have canned today) boiled it down to make the broth, removed the fat and shredded it prior to adding other ingredients. Stirred in half a pack of taco mix left over from another recipe in place of canned broth. so it wouldn't turn out too salty. Can't go wrong with this one!

text:
You can't get an easier recipe than this one.  I read a bunch of the reviews and incorporated alot of suggestions into my finished dish.  I used cooked chicken, not canned.  I also added a can of cream of chicken soup to the soup ingredients to thicken up the soup.  Next, cumin, chili powder, garlic powder, and the juice of one lime were added to the soup.  Toppings included sliced avocado, a dollop of sour cream, and some crushed tortilla chips.   (Oh, and a splash of Sriracha Sauce for added "heat".)  I cooked this in a crockpot on LOW for 5 hours.  I'm giving it 4 star based on my "tweaks".  I'm thinking the soup would be bland if made just as written.

text:
This is a great, fast, and easy recipe.  I do make some modifications, per my husband's and my tastes and other reviewer's suggestions:  1 large and 1 small can of chicken breast (who says canned chicken isn't any good?  I think it's great,) 1/2 can tomatoes with green chilis (since my husband isn't crazy about tomatoes), 1 can chicken broth and 2 cans cream of chicken soup.  The rest I leave the same.  I dump everything in a crock pot, adding some spices like garlic powder and chili powder, and let it go for a couple hours to let the flavors blend together.  It is delish!  I made it for some friends of ours for a weekend lunch and we barely had any left by the end of the afternoon.

text:
I modified this a bit since I like a bit of creaminess to my soups. From another review, I only used 1 can of chicken broth (reduced sodium) & I added 2 cans of cream of chicken soup. I also added cumin, paprika, chili powder & garlic powder. I simmer it all on low for about an hour to really blend it all together. Made this way it was awesome! Best torilla soup (and the easiest) I've ever had. Everyone loves it. Thanks for the keeper!

text:
I make a similar version of this by using my crockpot.  I put three or four skinless chickent breasts in first, then can of chicken broth, jar of medium salsa, can of corn (drained), can of black beans (drained)and can of fat free refried beans. Sprinkle in some chili powder, cayenne pepper and cumin.  Cook on low for 6 hours; pull chicken out and shredd and put back in for one more hour on low.  Hearty and healthy.  Freezes well too. Not six cans since I use fresh chicken, but close!

country:

text:
I was told that this was the best soup that I had ever made by my husband! 1 can or chicken broth, 2 cans of Cream of Chicken, 1 can of tomatoes w/ chilies, 1 can Corn and one can of black beans. I started out by cooking up some onions and garlic in a little olive oil. Then added all the cans together in the pot. Added cayenne pepper, cumin, pepper, chili powder and paprika to taste. Simmer these together for about a 1/2 hour for more flavor. Finally, I had some left over spicy grilled chicken that I threw in while the soup was on a super low setting. Then, let the ingredients come together for another 15 minutes and then serve. This made the chicken super moist and totally not overcooked! Fantastic!

I usually do not review recipes but I loved how easy this was and how great it tasted.  I drained the corn, chicken (& rinsed), beans, and tomatoes. This was super good!! I changed just a few things to suit our tastes. First, I poached 3 chicken breasts in chicken broth, minced garlic, salt and pepper; shredded and set aside. When I was ready to make the soup I sauteed 1 small onion and 2 tablespoons of minced garlic in the bottom of my pot. Threw in the chicken and the rest of the ingredients (I replaced one can of chicken broth with one can of cream of chicken soup), a handful of rice and 2 tablespoons of taco seasoning. Served with shredded cheese, sour cream and crushed tortilla chips.

text:
I, too, adore this recipe...it is a perfect last-minute low-maintenence dinner as you can ALWAYS have everything on hand and ready to go.  Who doesn't keep frozen chicken breasts in their freezer?  After reading many reviews and tinkering with this recipe for a year or so, I think I have perfected my family's preference.  I use one shredded chicken breast in place of canned, Mexi-corn instead of regular, 1 can of chicken broth, 1 can of cream of chicken, and 1 can of Campbell's Select Chicken Tortilla Soup.  I also season a little with cilantro, cumin, chili powder, and garlic powder.  And I garnish with whatever we have at the moment, but our favorite is strips of tortilla shells, some shredded cheese, and a dollop of sour cream.  If we don't have tortillas, we probably at least have tortilla chips so we'll crush those up as a substitute.  YUM!!

text:
Great recipe with a few modifications. I only used one 14.5 ounce can of chicken broth, and one can of condensed chicken soup (did not add water). Also, instead of canned chicken, I shredded some leftover rotisserie chicken. Also make sure to rinse the black beans really well or the soup will turn grey. To add some flavor, I added chopped jalapenos, cilantro, shredded cheese, then topped with sour cream. Hands down the easiest and one of the best tasting soups I've ever made!

text:
Economical and tasty! I took a few of the suggestions into account, and added about 1 tbsp of cumin, 2 tbsp of chopped cilantro, 1 tbsp of chili powder, and a tsp of garlic powder. Oh, make sure you rinse the beans really well so your soup doesn't turn gray! Instead of canned chicken, I used precut, precooked chicken (It was on sale for 79 cents for 10 oz due to the fact it had to be sold the next day). Also, I used 1 can of cream of chicken soup, and 1 can of broth, as opposed to the two cans of broth. I topped it all off with Mexican style shredded cheese. With these changes and additions, this soup is amazing! Even my stepmother raved and asked for the recipe. Thank you!

userID:
2059924
Display Name:
Sara Bosworth
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2001099.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last night. All I can say is YUMMY! My picky kids, toddler and hubby LOVED it! 

I used the correct base ingredients except for canned chicken and canned corn (I'm not a canned veggie user). I did season and spice it up as the other reviews advised. I added some cumin, chili powder, garlic powder, onion powder, cilantro, black pepper, a little sea salt and a small dash of cayenne pepper. I also added a half a jar of thick and chunky salsa and an ounce of low-fat cream cheese and a small handful of Kraft cheddar crumbles just to thicken the sauce a bit. I also added extra beans. I had some pinto beans that I needed to use so I rinsed and dumped those in. 

I served it with low-fat sour cream, shredded cheddar and Tostino's Natural Organic corn tortilla chips. I suggest the organic chips. They have a wonderful flavor! The regular chips taste like salt and grease, not the organics! The corn flavor comes through and there is not salty, greasy taste. Use the organics with this soup! This recipe could also, very easily, be turned into a vegetarian soup or you could add some ground beef. The possiblilities are endless with this recipe! 

This is a keeper in my house and I will definately use this as a 'company' recipe. It's not expensive, tastes great and you can easily make a ton. Plus there's only one dish to wash!

I made this recipe exactly as written - I even found all the cans in the same sizes - we must shop at the same store. (The chicken broth was "99% fat free", but isn't this usually more or less the case?) This dish turned out to be pretty tasty - my first impression was a 4-star rating. I don't know if it was the reheating or what, but leftovers the next day weren't quite as good.
However, I think that the suggestions in the recipe introduction, about the tortilla chips and shredded cheddar cheese, are "musts"; they added a lot to the dish. I thought the "serve over tortilla chips" idea sounded a little strange, but it worked well - just don't use too many, or you'll have a bunch of corn mush at the bottom of the soup bowl.

text:
I gave this four stars because I didn't follow the recipe exactly. My husband and I thought it was okay as is, but excellent with our changes. First, I substituted one can of chicken broth for cream of chicken soup, as many of the reviews suggested. Second, I added a medium-sized jar of mild salsa (or homemade if you have it) and that is what really brought the whole thing together. Third, we grill our own chicken or use leftovers from the night before. Fourth, chop up a zucchini and let it simmer until cooked through. The spiciness was definitely perfect and there was just enough of everything. Addition of the zucchini makes it super filling! This is a weekly staple at our house now. Thanks so much!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'd give this recipe 4.5 stars because it is really easy, really fast.  With some tweaking, it is easily a 5 star recipe that the hubby actually LOVES (he actually requests this soup, and he NEVER requests anything else but heavy italian pasta dishes!).  If you can swing it, use leftover shredded chicken instead of the canned, although the canned is OK in a pinch (I use grilled chicken breasts with a bit of southwest grill seasoning). To make the soup a bit thicker, I used creamed corn instead of plain canned corn, and added 1 C. finely crushed white corn tortilla chips.  I skipped the taco seasoning that others have suggested and simply added 1/2 tsp. cumin.  Simmer the pot for 15 to 20 minutes and the corn chips act like flour to thicken the soup.  Serve topped with shredded cheddar or mexican blend cheese.  WOW!!  Hubby has already asked that I prepare a triple batch for him to share with the guys during deer season, instead of chili.  Thanks for the recipe - definitely a keeper and has been added to my monthly rotation!

I have been using this basic recipe for years.  It is a snap to make in the crock pot!  As you can see from all of the different suggestions in the reviews, you can modify it depending on your tastes and what you have on hand. Whenever I have leftover grilled or roasted chicken, I cut it into bite sized pieces and freeze for later to use for this recipe.

text:
This was really good, especially with a little spicing up. I used a can of Fiesta corn instead of plain, and seasoned the soup with chili powder and a little garlic and onion salt. Next time I will probably use the hot rotel instead of regular...but there will definitely be a next time. Sour cream, shredded cheddar and crushed tortilla chips really make it great.
UPDATE: Changing this to a 5. Used low sodium ingredients, and only had to use a little chili powder to spice it up this time. Also, I like to take my hand mixer and run it through the soup to shred the canned chicken a little more. This is a great recipe, so simple and tasty.

To make this a vegetarian recipe, I substituted a can of cut green beans (sticking with the canned vegetable theme) for the chunk chicken and vegetable broth for the chicken broth.  I added 1 t cumin and a sprinkling of garlic powder, included the tortilla chip and cheese recommendation, and this turned out to be such a pleasing and easy recipe.

text:
We loved this!  I couldn't believe the canned chicken turned out so well in this soup.  I made just a few modifications- I sliced up some green onions for color and sauteed them for a few minutes in olive oil and garlic.  I also added fresh ground black pepper and some cumin. Then I added everything else and simmered.  I refrigerated it overnight to let the flavors blend, and served it the next night.  Instead of the tortilla chips, my husband cut some flour tortillas into stips, seasoned them, and baked on a cookie sheet until lightly browned.  Soup was delicious with the tortilla strips, sour cream and shredded cheddar. I'll try some pepper jack and a couple of dashes of Tobasco next time.  Thanks for a recipe that is so quick and easy for a busy working mom!

I really liked this recipe.  Yes, fresh chicken would have been better but the canned did good in a pinch.  Hubby wasn't too impressed with the flavor.  He said it was bland.  Next time, I will use HOT Rotel instead of mild, I guess.  I should have rinsed the beans, but recipe doesn't even call for draining them.  

My additions to this recipe were; saffron rice,  fresh avacado (chopped with fresh lime juice), (just a touch of) fresh cilatro, fresh chopped green onions and shreaded Monterey Jack cheese.  I topped already dished out soup with the above for an attractive dish.

text:
Super quick and easy! My suggestions: Add 1 can cream of chicken soup (if you like it thicker, replace one of the cans of broth). Try Rotel's "Chili Fixins", it's diced tomatoes, chilis, and a chili powder seasoning. Also, instead of black beans, use a can of Del Monte Savory Sensations "Rio Grande Vegetables". It's Pinto beans, tomatoes, corn, green chilis in a spicy sauce. Served this over the chips with shredded cheddar cheese, fresh tomatoes, avacado, and sour cream. Yum. Yum.

text:
I doubled this and took it to a pot-luck dinner.  Everyone was raving about how good it was, and there wasn't a drop left.  I made a couple of changes: I used frozen corn, only 1 can of the diced tomatoes w/green chile (the can I bought was pretty spicy!), and sauteed some chicken tenders.  I used frozen chicken tenders - did you know you could just saute them while they're frozen? :)  Then I diced them into bite sized pieces.  The broken-up tortilla chips are a must as a topping.  I threw all the ingredients into my slow cooker for a few hours to blend the flavors....Delicious!

text:
I changed this recipe a little because I don't eat chicken so I used veg broth instead and left out the chicken. I only used one can of broth because I like my soup thick, and then I cooked a cup of rice in the other can of broth, I used jasmine. I added the rice to the soup after it was cooked and then heated it a little more. I put some cheddar cheese on top and had a wonderful soup for dinner. I took some the next day for lunch but all the rice had soaked up the rest of the broth, so I had beans and rice insead of soup but it was delicious, I personally liked it much more than the soup, but I'm not a huge soup fan. Try the rice, it makes for amazing leftovers. And monterey jack cheese would be better than cheddar.

text:
This recipe couldn't have been any easier.  Instead of canned chicken I used chicken breasts and just cooked them in the chicken broth with some added cumin and cilantro.  Then I chopped up the chicken tossed it back in, threw in the rest of the ingredients (along with an extra can of chicken stock) and let it heat through.

text:
After eating a heaping bowl garnished with avocado, cilantro, cheddar cheese, sour cream and crushed tortilla chips, my husband announced, "That was great!  We have to have that again."  I added fresh cilantro and about a 1/2 teaspoon of cumin to boost the flavor a bit.  I didn't have Rotel, so substituted a can of diced tomatoes and a can of diced green chiles.  This was a very hearty and delicious meal in a bowl.  I know what I'm having for lunch tomorrow!

UPDATE:  I substituted one can of cream of chicken soup for one can of broth and this added some dimension to this soup.

text:
Great & soooo easy to make. I used 3 fresh chicken breasts sliced into thin strips & cooked for a few minutes in a bit of olive oil with 1 clove of garlic. Then added the cans, along with 1 can of diced green chiles & 1 can of cream of ckn in place of 1 ckn broth. Sprinkled on some cayenne pepper, 1 tsp. of cumin, and a few dashes of hot sauce. Served with tortilla chips for dipping and shredded monterey jack cheese. Delicious.

text:
SUPER CHEAP & EASY TO MAKE!  If you can use a can opener, you can make this!  Only thing I did differently was not use the chicken in a can.  I buy chicken breasts by the bag and I keep them in the freezer.  I defrosted 2 pieces in the microwave a litte and then I boiled them until they were cooked through...set aside and let cool.  After the soup was ready, I tore apart the chicken and added it to the soup.  I garnished the soup with crushed tortilla chips, montery jack cheese, a dolop of sour cream and sliced avacado!  It was SO good!!!!!!!  I will make it again and again!

text:
WOW! This is the most DELICIOUS thing I have ever made. I used one 9-oz. package of frozen grilled chicken strips in place of the canned chicken, and added 1/8 cup each of fresh cilantro and green onions, with a pinch of garlic and taco seasoning to taste. It was VERY spicy when first cooked, but by the second day in the fridge the flavors had really blended together. A dollop of sour cream cools it down nicely. I can't wait to cook this again - it was SO easy, and really yummy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just wanted to comment on the salt content. As one person noted, the chicken broth is a big offender when it comes to sodium. However, ALL of the ingredients are big offenders. These are all canned foods, and canned foods use salt as part of the preservation process. Every one of them has far more salt than necessary. If you want to cut it down, try using frozen corn, low sodium chicken broth, and cooking your own beans and chicken. On the bright side, it'll taste better. On the bad side, it'll take longer. Note-Black beans dodo not need to be soaked like most other dried beans.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this soup on  New Years' eve for many reason.  The temperature now is 6 degress in northern IL and I have a head/chest cold that is kicking my butt so wanted something quick. I started with a few chicken breast and cooked them in water to cover and added 2 chicken bouillon cubes and small diced onion.  I shredded the chicken when done and added the drained corn, rinsed beans and undrained tomatoes. I added enough chicken broth to the desired consistency and then added chili powder, cumin and garlic powder to taste.  Unfortunately, I lost my taste buds too but my husband liked it. This is a good base recipes. If you like a creamier soup, add the condensed cream of chicken soup.

text:
This is my favorite soup in the world but (like everybody else on this website) I make changes to it.  Rotel is too sharp for our tastes.  So we use three cans of diced tomatoes and one can of green chilies.  We also put in a can of red beans, not just black ones.  I also put in two cans of chicken, not just one, and use a sack of taco seasoning and three Tbs of dry ranch dressing mix.  Is it still your soup?  Probably not.   It has lots more cans and it's just scrumptious.

text:
I give this recipe to new brides at bridal showers.  (Could give the ingredients too!)  I bake corn tortillas in the oven at 400 degrees for about 5 minutes; then crumble into soup.  You can make queso to go on extra crispy tortillas by melting velveta cheese slices and either salsa or a few spoonfuls of chopped rotel tomatoes; melted in the microwave.  I usually add a little milk too.  Easy; quick, and pretty healthy!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give it three stars because as written it is a bit bland, but it serves as a good base recipe for your own version with whatever you like to taste. I've made this recipe many times in different ways depending on what I have on hand. Right now I have it cooking in the crockpot with frozen chicken tenderloins, 3.5 cups chicken broth made with three chicken bouillon and water, a packet of taco seasoning, one can sweet corn (drained and rinsed), one can black beans (also drained and rinsed), one can diced tomatoes and about 1/8 cup diced frozen jalapeno from this summer's garden. I'll remove and shred the chicken when done, in about three hours on high. Give it a try!

text:
I was looking for a recipe that would take advantage of leftover stewed chicken from taco night. I'm so glad I found this! Due to the amount of chicken I had I doubled the amount of corn, tomatoes, and stock (I use reduced sodium stock) and through in the black beans from said taco night. What I ended up with is a lovely tex-mex like stew, with a texture similar to Brunswick stew. Served with cornbread, this was a huge hit and helped me make my chicken go even farther.  I think this will be a permanent addition to the dinner lineup after taco night. :D

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great and quick recipe, easy to throw together in a pinch and more often than not I have what I need in the pantry already.  Easy to modify too, if I don't have diced tomatoes with green chilies I just use regular (or fresh) diced tomatoes and throw in something else to heat it up a bit (green chilies, chopped up peppers, chili powder, etc.).  Very forgiving with quantity changes too and a lot of fun to play around with, I haven't made a bad version yet.  I personally don't mind the canned chicken, it's easy enough to make this a nice complex flavor that will mask the bland canned chicken flavor with ease.

userID:
11634627
Display Name:
kirby1kat
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
1616
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this for years.  I buy 2 cans of chicken tortilla soup in the Mexican section of the grocery store and proceed to kick it up several notches! I add a can of thoroughly rinsed and drained black beans. Instead of canned, I shred a store-bought rotisserie chicken, using about 1 1/2 cups of the meat, saving the rest for another recipe. Instead of the canned tomatoes w/ chilies, plus approx. 1 tsp of ground cumin and 1 jar of salsa (any 'heat'). This makes the soup pretty thick so I usually add 1-2 cans of chicken broth. Taste and adjust the seasonings. I then serve the soup over roughly broken lime-flavored tortilla chips, lite sour cream & Monterrey Jack - Colby Cheese blend or Mexican Cheese blend. Easy, so wonderfully filling & low in calories (especially if you don't use the tortilla chips). You have to give this a try!!

text:
Great basic recipe that can be easily customized.  We add about half a package of taco seasoning to give it just the right amount of kick.  Be sure to rinse the canned beans to help cut down the sodium content.  We like our soups spicy and hearty, so we use regular "full strength" Rotel.  Rotisserie chicken or the John Soules pre-cooked chicken packets make a heartier version.  This recipe is so easy -- I highly recommend.

text:
I made this according to directions, but opened a can of cream style corn instead of regular.  I had already added two cans of broth, so my soup was a bit thin.  Next time I may use the creamed corn with just one can of broth.  The soup was a bit bland, so I added around a teaspoon each of cumin and chili powder and a little onion and garlic powder.  My husband thought it was great and couldn't believe it was from 6 cans!  Next time I'll try to use a rotisserie chicken, but the canned was all I had on hand this time.  This is a great recipe to pull together from pantry ingredients on short notice!

text:
Quick,simple, Delicious,and filling! I did take the advice of the reviews and tweaked it a bit. This is what I did: I rinsed the black beans, I used a rotisserie chicken that I got at the market instead of canned chicken (meat in a can just didn't sound yummy to me), one can of chicken broth and two cans of condensed cream of chicken soup (I didn't add water) and I added a bit chili powder and a dash of garlic powder. We topped it off with shredded cheese and a dollop of sour cream, and dipped our tortilla chips in it. FABULOUS! especially when you're in a rush, I think it tool a total of 10 minutes! Will definitely be making this again.

So very simple but so very good. I took some of other reviewers suggestions like 1 can of broth 1 can of cream of chicken. Next time I won't use a can of water to thin it out. I like it thicker. I also added 1/4 t of red chili flake, cayenne & paprika and 1/2 T of chili powder. Since this is the 2nd time I'm making it I decided to rinse off the black beans so the soup wouldn't have an an off putting color and hand shredded the chicken chunks so it would be more evenly distributed.
