text:
Even my kids ate this, thanks for the recipe!  I followed others suggestions and added a lot more seasonings like cumin, chili powder and crushed garlic.  First I brought 4 C of chicken broth to boil, threw in a whole chicken breast to cook and took it out just before it was done instead of using  canned chicken.  After that the rest of the ingredients were added.  Pulled the chicken apart, added it back in and got out the hand blender  till I got the "thicker" consistency I wanted.  Only had one key lime so I cut it in half, squeezed it and threw it into the soup to really get the lime flavour.  Will definitely make this again!

text:
Driving home last night was our first cold spell and I thought about how good a hot soup would be for the office today.  I grabbed an oven roasted chicken and the ingredients for this.  Everyone raved about how good it was and wanted the recipe.  After reading the reviews I took away one of the cans of broth and added a can of condensed cream of chicken and added no water.  I drained and rinsed the black beans, drained the corn and otherwise made it per the directions.  I did add cumin, a little onion powder and garlic salt, along with fresh cracked pepper, salt along with chipotle pepper and some cayenne pepper.  It kicked like a mule!  I was even surprised at how good it turned out.  Topped it off with some extra sharp cheddar, sour cream and popped a cluster of tostitos hint of lime chips around the bowls.  This is some really good eatin!

Display Name:
glchick

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/929475.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy comfort food and fast!  You can add almost anything to the basic recipe including left over veggies, but here are the basics.  Use real chicken, not canned.  Either rotisserie or just bake a couple of boneless chicken breasts rubbed with a little olive oil, salt and pepper for about 20 minutes.  Rinse the black beans well.  Use 1 can broth and 1 can cream of chicken soup.  Add 1 tsp each of cumin and chili powder (or more to taste).

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
This soup is delish!!!!  Like others before me-I did a little substituting but not much!  Subbed one can of broth for one can of cream of chicken, used a roasted chicken from the grocery store (HEB).  I added fresh chopped cilantro, chili powder, garlic powder and a little salt.  Served in a bowl with sliced avocado and a dollop of sour cream on top...didn't need any tortilla chips.  Absolutely fabulous and we got two meals from it!  I highly highly recommend!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you are looking for an easy to put together, fast, and adaptable recipe- this one fits the bill... I tried this recipe last night.  Based on the other reviews I doctored it up. I was being lazy and since I am slightly opposed to canned chicken; I used a rotisserie chicken from the supermarket in lieu of.  I also used a little extra chicken broth and drained and rinsed the beans and corn, and drained the diced tomotoes- I used a can of fire roasted diced tomatoes, and spiced it up with some chipotle chili powder- if you don't like spicy I would recommend some fresh cilantro. Let this simmer for an hour or so, and then served it with some shredded extra sharp cheddar, a dab of sour cream, and some blue corn tortilla chips.

Made this soup for my book club group....this isn't a well known soup in Atlantic Canada so the ladies' didn't know what to expect...they LOVED it!!!
I did take advice from the comments....substituted 1 can of broth with low fat cream of chicken - rinsed the black beans real well - used rotisserie chicken instead of canned - added cumin, chili powder and garlic powder.

Thank you for the fabulous recipe and all the valuable comments/advice !!!

text:
Good way to use up canned chicken, or for that leftover broth thats in your fridge! I drained and rinsed the beans, and sauteed an onion first before adding everything together. 

Also, by suggestion of other reviewers, I used cream of chicken to thicken it up but cornstarch would work too.

So easy and yummy with a little hot sauce.

text:
This soup came out great AFTER modifications. It needs seasoning. I used chicken bouillon, chili powder, Mediterranean spices & onion powder. After ladling the key ingredient was grated sharp cheddar. It was sooo good and healthy. I also used a rotisserie chicken and cream style corn for one of the two cans I used (doubled recipe). It came together in 10 mins. It was great simmering on low all Sunday afternoon as the family was in an out eating at all different times. Will definitely be making this often because it was so easy, healthy, & delicious.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is perfect. As a college student on a limited budget, I'm often in search of hearty meals for a cheap price--and this fits the bill. However, as a warning, I didn't quite follow the recipe. I like soups thick and creamy (and the local grocery store was out of chicken broth), so I used two cans cream of chicken. I'm also more fond of kidney beans than black, so I used those, rinsed. But I think what made it perfect was the chilies in the tomatoes. It gave it the perfect kick. I love it. Hearty and tasty. I have lunch for the week. Bought some cantaloupe and tortillas to have with it. Seriously, perfect college food when you have a kitchen. I'm excited.

text:
This is excellent. I modified it slightly (out of necessity) into a slow-cooker recipe. I had on hand 1 can each, chili and black beans, 1 can diced tomatoes with green chilies, 1 can corn, and 1 can mild enchilada sauce (red). I added the Cumin and Chili powder as suggested and the two cups water and 2 chicken boullion cubes. I popped in some chicken breasts (3 cut up) and slow cooked 1 hr. on high, and 6-7 on low. Served with lime tortilla chips--YUM!!!  Rave reviews from everyone!

text:
EXCELLENT soup with the additions everyone else here has mentioned. I added black pepper, cayenne pepper, chili powder (yes i love the spicy kick), cumin, rotisserie chicken (instead of canned), lots of cilantro, a dash of adobo. I also agree with substituting 1/2 of the chicken broth with cream of chicken soup to thicken up the consistency. I haven't had tortilla soup this amazing since I went to an authentic restaurant in El Salvador 4 years ago. GREATTTT easy recipe.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed many of the suggestions in the other reviews and was THRILLED with the result!  I have been obsessed with Moe's Southwest Grille's Chicken Tortilla soup and now can make my own comparable version! 

I used 32 oz (UNCONDENSED) chicken broth, 1 can each of Cream of Chicken and 98% Fat Free Cream of Chicken soup (do not add water), 1 small chopped yellow onion, Green Giant Mexicorn  to take advantage of the red and green peppers (drained), 1 can of organic black beans (drained and rinsed very, very well), 1 can diced tomatoes with mild green chiles (not drained, just dump on in), and the canned chicken breast in water.  Added salt, pepper, chili powder and garlic power to taste. Threw all in one big pot and simmered over medium heat until it looked done.  I am going to be making this ALL THE TIME! Thank you for the suggestions and great original base recipe!

text:
I am not exaggerating when I say that this is the best soup ever! It's hearty, zesty, and oh-so-easy to make! 

I made the following adjustments to the recipe: I substituted one of the cans of broth for a 10.5oz can of cream of chicken to keep it from being watery. I also added 1 tsp cumin, 1/2 tsp chili powder, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp creole seasoning, and a big handful of freshly chopped cilantro leaves. I also garnished the finished soup with tortilla strips and Mexican blend shredded cheese. 

This recipe is so tasty and quick to make that I will be making it two nights in a row! I would recommend it to everyone.

I rate this 5 stars but only using other's suggestions. I added spices such as cumin, onion powder, pepper, and cayanne pepper for some much needed heat. I also added minced garlic. In place of canned chicken I shredded store bought roasted chicken (easy & it makes a BIG difference).

Display Name:
Anna-Bat
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/340124.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A simple foundation to work from to make an excellent soup.  Instead of using canned chicken, I boiled two small boneless skinless chicken breasts and shredded them.  I sauteed half an onion in the pot before adding all the other ingredients.  As per other reviews I substituted one can of chicken broth for a can of condensed cream of chicken soup.  I also added 1 tsp ground cumin and 1/2 tsp ground chipotle pepper to give it a little spice/heat.  Served with tortilla chips and some grated cheddar.  It was a big hit with the boyfriend.

As a note, I forgot to rinse the black beans before adding them, and it definitely gives the soup a kind of brownish-gray color which looks slightly unappetizing but doesn't affect the taste.  If serving to company or don't want grayish soup, I'd recommend rinsing the beans!

city:

country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe... but also made small adjustments. Instead of the chicken broth I used one can of cream of chicken soup with one large rectangle of  Maggi's (or Knorr) chicken buillon with 2 cups of water. Mixed that well together first then added the remaider ingredients. Also, for the tomatoes I used a can of mild Rotel and I rinsed the black beans before mixing them in, so that they would not give the soup a greyish appearance. My husband and kids loved it. It was just right in the spice department for us and my husband added hot sauce to his. We all added shredded Mexican Cheese blend and some of us chose to add a dollop of sour cream. The best part of this recipe? You can always have htose cans in your pantry and meal is ready in 15 minutes!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a fantastic base.  I made it according to directions the first time with sides of cheese, tortilla chips, and avocado on the table.  I’ve since made this recipe multiple times and true to form have doctored it up many different ways.  I make my own stock weekly and this is a great way to reduce the sodium in this soup.  I like to roast a chicken on Sunday and the leftover dark meat is great to throw in the pot.  (The carcass gets used for stock the next week.)  I usually throw in some combination of cumin, Tabasco, cilantro, garlic, and maybe a few bits of onion if it’s left over from something else.  This is a great recipe to always have the ingredients on hand and customize it to whomever you’re cooking for.  Just always remember the avocado and tortilla chips!  Thank you for an amazing base recipe.  The boyfriend always gives it a double thumbs up, and is always disappointed when he orders this at restaurants.  He always says “It’s not as good as yours.”

text:
This is an excellent base as noted by other reviewers...I used 2 cans of chicken broth (1 with low sodium), 1 can of cream of chicken soup, 1 can of rotel, 1 can of red gold "chili ready" diced tomatoes, a can of rinsed and drained black beans, a bag of frozen corn and a can of chunk white chicken. I seasoned with California style garlic salt, adobo seasoning, and fresh ground pepper. We toasted a couple of loaves of sweet italian bread seasoned with the California garlic salt and olive oil spray and dipped it since I didn't have tortillas, chips, or crackers on hand. Very easy and very delish:) Even my 3 picky children loved it!! It really does need "tweaked" to fit your family but that's the easy part since you know your tastes!

text:
I just made this recipe for the first time. I did as others suggested, and changed a few things. I used 2 boneless skinless chicken breasts, boiled and shredded, 1 tsp chili powder, sprinkled with garlic salt, 1 tsp cumin, 2 cans of reduced fat condensed cream of chicken soup (in place of 1 of the chicken broth cans), 1 can of chicken broth, 1 cup of water and left everything else the same. I dumped it all into the crock pot for a few hours. I added shredded cheese and baked flour tortillas on 350 for a few minutes, cut them up and added them as well. Great recipe and easy too. Thank you=) This one's going in my favorites=)

text:
I just got done making this recipe at my parents' house, and I must say that it got quite the reception.  I did note a few user suggestions and made a few of my own, though.  For one I substituted a can of condensed cream of chicken soup for one of the cans of broth.  Also, I added cumin, dried cilantro, and about 4 canned chipotle chiles (chopped) and some adobo sauce that they were packed with, it added a nice smokey flavor and a real good punch to the dish.  I also used the canned corn that had some green/red chiles in it.  I did drain the black beans, and I didnt completely drain the juice from the stewed tomatoes.  Definitely will make this cheap, easy dish again.

text:
This is a great recipe, however, add-ins are a must!  Can't get any better than this for a weeknight dinner -cheap fast and easy! I also subbed cream of chicken soup for one of the cans of broth as well as a jar of fire-roasted salsa instead of the canned tomatoes.  I used canned chicken because I had some on hand that needed to be used, but will definitely be using fresh next time.  I added about a c. frozen diced onion, 1/4 c. finely chopped cilantro, 1.5 T. lime juice, 2 oz can diced green chiles, 3 cloves finely chopped garlic, and seasoned to taste with chili powder and cumin.  Turned out great...my picky hubby said he would have eaten 5 bowls if he could've :)
Thanks Terryn!

text:
Wow!  So easy!  I was skeptical becuase of its simplicity, but I did make a few tweaks.  I didn't have any cream of chicken and all the reviews raved about adding it, so I melted 2Tbsp butter with 2 Tbsp flour and 1 cup of milk.  I added that to a chicken breast boiled in water with celery, onion and thyme (about 45 mins).  Added a can of corn, rinsed black beans and diced tomates.  Once I threw in cumin and some chili powder, it was perfect!

text:
Great starter recipie. For mine, I use 1 can of cream of chicken soup, 1 can of chicken broth, 1 frozen chicken breast, 1 can of whole kernel corn drained, 1 can of black beans drained and rinsed, 1 can of Rotel drained, 1 tablespoon of chili powder, and 1 teaspoon of Cumin. Put all ingredients in a crock pot on low, give it a stir and 8 hours later.. delicious soup. I serve it with tortilla chips, sour cream, and shredded cheddar cheese. There are NEVER any left overs!

Sauteed about 1/2 c of onion in pot before adding ingredients.  Left out the corn, added 1 can of cream of chicken soup, drained the black beans and Rotel tomatoes. text:
Scrumptious and EASY.  Modifications were simple, thanks to an easy recipe and the great suggestions of other reviewers.  I used 1/2 of a roasted chicked purchased at the grocery store, 2 cans of the regular Rotel chopped tomatoes and chilis, 1 can of cream of chicken soup along with cilantro, cumin, and garlic.  After sampling the soup I determined the regular Rotel added too much of a bite and toned it done a tad by adding another can of chicken broth and a can of potatoes (chopped).
Served with tortilla chips and topped with sour cream brought the spice down a tad more, making it easier on hubbies palate.  Personally, I love the spice but others may want to go with the MILD Rotel.

text:
This was a good base recipe, so I gave it 4 stars, but with the additions I made, it was 5! I diced up an onion and cooked it a few minutes with some garlic, and then added the rest of the ingredients (minus the chicken, as I didn't have any). I added some frozen corn, cumin, chili powder, and threw in about 1/2 cup rice and then covered and simmered about 15 minutes (until the rice was cooked). I just served it up, and put a big spoonful of sour cream on top, which made it creamy and smooth (and cooled it down a bit). I just had my second bowl! I followed others reviews and rinsed the black beans first too. This went great with my cheese tortilla! thanks for the recipe, I'll def make this again soon.

text:
This was so delicious and easy to make!  I made a couple of changed based on past reviews.  First, I replaced one can of the broth with cream of chicken soup, then I substituted the black beans with white cannellini beans.  I also boiled and shredded some chicken instead of using the canned.  At the end, I mixed in a little cornstarch with water to thicken it up.  It was really good!  My 3 year old son ate 2 bowls of it and the next day, went to the refridgerator and pulled out the bowl of leftovers and asked me to make it for him for his lunch.  I served shredded cheese and crushed tortilla chips on top.  I'll be making this one a lot!  Thanks for sharing!

4 stars as is, 5 with  a lot of add in's. My husband thought that some cooked rice in it would have been a nice addition.  I put it all in the slow cooker and let it go for a good part of the day, it was wonderful and also VERY good reheated.  have to serve it with cheese and tortilla strips on top!

text:
This was awesome, it was fast,delicious and even better the next day. I read some reviews and altered it just a bit.

What I did was put the diced chicken ( I would recommend one more can of chicken) in the pot first, I turned on the burner and seasoned it with garlic salt and a dash of crushed red pepper, then I added all of the ingredients eliminating about half the Swansons chicken, adding two cans of condensed cream of chicken soup and a splash of Franks Red Hot sauce, some corn chips at the bottom of a bowl, topped with soup, a dollop of sour cream,finished off with mexican blend shredded cheese and voila a yummy dinner! This is definately a keeper!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
UNBELIEVABLY GOOD, and incredibly versatile: with minor additions you could have a rustic stew, spicy Latino fare, an herbed garden soup or a distictive Eastern European taste.  For the first time around I altered only to make more soup for our big crew.  Doubled the chicken broth, doubled the tomatoes, one can each of kidney and pinto beans, plus a handful of uncooked white rice.  Simmered until the rice was done.  No leftovers.  I might suggest running the tinned tomatoes through a blender, as I found the beans/rice/chicken made the texture of the tomatoes seem off by comparison.  This recipe is now in our permanent rotation.

text:
Had to agree with a previous reviewer that this soup had an odd color...almost gray.  I carefully drained the black beans hoping to avoid the unappetizing color but I expected more of a chickeny, healthy yellow color.  Used Rotel tomotoes with chilis as they add a nice kick.  I think the canned chicken resulted in an unusual smell.  Would definitely not use canned meat again.  I prepared this for a soup and salad buffet on Christmas Day.  The Shrimp Bisque (The Soup Mix Gourmet) went over big but the Chicken Tortilla barely got a nod.  Won't make it again.....wish I could have given a better review.

text:
This recipe is fabulous! My mother, who is an amazing from scratch cook, requested this for her birthday dinner.  I added to things to the recipe.  First I sauteed some mixed frozen celery, onion, and red pepper in just a little bit of veg. oil.  Then I added everything plus half a pack of taco seasoning.  A quick and easy way to add some spice, plus it thickened it so it was heartier.  We topped it off with reduced fat cheese and low fat sour cream with the soup on light tortilla chips.  Delicious and still healthy!

JADISENE

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been using this recipe for a couple of years now, ever since I found it on this site. It's really surprisingly great for being so simple. 

Like others here, I've made a few adjustments. Personally instead of canned chicken, I either use fresh chicken (or fajita seasoned raw chicken) and cook it before I start, or I get southwestern flavored chicken pieces already cooked from the fresh or frozen meat section. 

I use regular canned diced tomatoes without the green chile peppers so I use a few seasonings to give it an extra bite : cumin, cayenne pepper, and onion powder more liberally, then just a dash of black pepper.
Review:
Rating:

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
WOW!  This is a great soup!  My family loves it.  It is great how it is, although my family likes it with a little spice.  I use seasoned black beans, drained a little but not rinsed, tomatoes with mild green chiles not drained, and instead of caned chicken I buy Tyson's Southwestern Seasoned Chicken Strips found in the freezer section.  I cut the chicken into cubes.  I also add chile powder, oragano, cumin and the juice of one lime.  We top our soup with tortilla chips, cheese and cubed avacado.  This soup is so good the second day I double the recipe.

text:
My husband and I both thought this was pretty good.  My 10 year old son hated it.  He soesn't like beans.  I especially like how easy it was to prepare.  I didn't use canned chicken, instead I cooked 2 large chicken breasts in chicken broth in my crock pot and shredded it into the soup.  I also drained and rinsed the beans.  Placed crushed tortilla chips in each bowl, ladeled the soup on top, topped with a dollop of sour cream and shredded Jack cheese and served with sourdough rolls.  Like I said my husband and I thought it was pretty tasty but my son gave it a thumbs-down.

text:
I meant to write a review for this recipe a couple of weeks ago, but I forgot to! We used this recipe on our recent camping trip just a few weeks ago and it was great! We had a large group of fellow campers, so we increased the amount several times. Kids and grownups alike loved this and everybody went for seconds. There were a couple of additions we made to it that I think made it even better. Firstly, we added more chicken. It needed it. Secondly, we brought along some chopped cilantro, ground cumin and ground chili powder. We added medium amounts of these and it was really awesome! We served it along with corn chips, sour cream and grated cheese. This is definately something that would be great to make at home as well. Thanks so much, Terry!

Used two cans cream cx soup, 1 can broth, toms with green chillie's , only drained my black beans, added cumin, red pepper flakes, and cajun seasoning, and WOW is the end result.  Never so impressed with seven CANS of ingrediants in all my days in the kitchen.  Thanks to those who posted such great tips!!

This was a super easy recipe that offered a good base to an eventually terrific Chicken Tortilla soup. Reading the recipe, I got the feeling it was going to be bland. text:
Pretty much everyone  giving  5 stars has made changes. Some that entirely change the recipe as written. As written, it’s ok. Not fantastic, but in a pinch of ‘I gotta feed the kids and don’t have the time Or energy’ it’s ok. Canned chicken, though.... was not a fan (and yes, I purposely bought it just for this recipe because you never know....). While I love suggestions and different ways to make a recipe better or tailor to preferences, I also would like to see reviews that prepared the recipe as is. Otherwise, you are rating your own recipe which defeats the purpose. On that note, it is a halfway decent base for you to work off of and create your very own recipe.

7033438
Display Name:
Nonnisaysmangia
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave it 2 stars because nobody liked it as is. The next time, I made several changes taken from the reviews and added one of my own, so it's no longer the same recipe. But, my family loves the changes. So what I did was buy rotisserie chicken, strip it down and put meat aside. Boiled the carcass in 4 c water for an hour or so, letting water cook down some. Strained the water into  Dutch oven, added 2 cans cream of chicken and a can of green chopped chilis and a can of creamed corn in addition to recipe. Garlic powder, onion powder, chili powder, cumin, 2 pinches cinnamon and 2 pinches of sugar. Lastly added the chicken, shredded up and heated it all to comfortable eating temp. Served with cheddar & cotillo cheeses, tortilla strips and sliced Mexican green onions and some avocado cubes. My son added hot sauce to his bowl. Creamy without being too thick or too soupy. Boiling step can be replaced with canned broth, of course and recipe is still easy peasy; just a bit "eh" (for us) as written.

text:
I've made this recipe several times, but with some additions. I don't use canned chicken (why? gross), instead I boil boneless beasts until JUST done, and cube. Used large cream of chicken soup, with the can filled about halfway with water, just to get some water and the soup that won't come out with a spoon into the crock pot. I don't add any broth.  I add chili powder, a little cilantro, salt, pepper, minced garlic, minced died onion, chipotle chili powder,   and adobo seasoning.  My family loves it!  My husband takes the leftovers to work and they request I make it a few times every winter !

text:
I have made this twice now.  The changes I made were to add one can of cream of chicken soup.  Because the can I had was only 10 oz, I also added 20 oz of chicken broth.  This didn't cause the recipe to have too much liquid.  I also chopped up a Rotisserie chicken both times too.  When you have very little time to prepare a meal, this recipe is perfect.  You can start heating all of your ingredients on the stove while you are adding the chicken and it's done in no time.  We never have left overs with this one.

text:
Made this last night for dinner.  It was really good and hubby even commented on it. I did not follow the recipe exactly, but did stick close to it. I did not have canned chicken, used raw chicken breast; did not have canned tomatoes and green chilies together, instead used 1-14.5 ounce can of petite diced tomatoes and 1-4 ounce can of chopped green chilies. Also, since there seemed to be not many seasonings, I added 1-1/2 tablespoons homemade taco seasoning mix from this site. I will definitely make it again. I try to follow a WW diet plan and a "0 points" soup is a big plus.

This was quite good. The best part was how quick and easy it was. I had it on the table in 30 minutes. The only  minor changes I made were that I sautéed 1/2 chopped onion in the pot with cooking spray, added minced garlic, drained the beans and added a bit of salsa and a generous squeeze of lime. I’m on Weight Watchers and this soup is zero smart points. It was tasty, filling, and satisfying. Will definitely make again!

text:
Great concept, but it needs some help in the spice department.  I added a can of cream of chicken soup and used rotisserie chicken instead of canned.  I suggest adding a generous combination of cumin, garlic, salt, chile powder, and whatever else sounds good to you.  I also added a dollop of sour cream and grated cheese to the serving bowl.  It was very good after the additions!  Crushed tortilla chips would have been good, too, but I didn't have any.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made a version of this for years that is super delicious and I carry it everywhere we have a pot luck.  A few changes to make - instead of canned corn use a small bag of frozen corn and instead of Rotel use a dip size jar of your favorite chunky salsa.  Add regular size can of unsalted refried beans as your "thickening" and 1/2 cup shredded cheddar cheese.  Put in crock pot until corn is thawed and warmed through (on high for an hour is what I do).  Serve with tortilla scoops and sprinkle grated cheese on top.

text:
This was a winner but the first thing you learn by reading the other reviews is that this recipe forms the base and from there you need to get creative.  I substituted the condensed cream of chicken soup for one of the cans of chicken broth, like others have.  For the other can, I used about 20 oz. of broth.  I seasoned the soup with a teaspoon of chili seasoning that I made from another Allrecipes recipe.  You will find that one listed under Chili Seasoning Mix II.  Lastly, I topped each bowl of soup with tortilla strips when I served them.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I doubled the recipe so I used a box of low sodium chicken stock and two cans of Cream of Chicken with Herbs soup.  To the mix I added one tsp. chili powder, one tsp. garlic powder, 1-1/2 tsps paprika, 1 tsp cumin and 1 tsp cilantro.  Instead of canned chicken I bought a rotisserie chicken, removed the bones and put the whole thing in the pot. The black beans, whole kernel corn and Ro-Tel tomatoes were drained and rinsed before adding to the soup.  I let the soup simmer on the stove for awhile stirring occasionally.  When served I had shredded cheddar cheese, sour cream and plain tortilla chips to put in the soup.  It was delicious!!  My husband loved it.  Next time I might try it with some avocado added.  Easy AND great tasting.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yes, I made a few changes and it was fantastic.  Turned into a very hearty meal. Instead of canned corn, use frozen (I believe it was a 10oz bag).  Use can of diced tomatoes (I used the kind without chile peppers), but then I added 3/4 of a regular jar of mild Picante salsa.  Use 2 cans of chunk chicken instead of 1 (Kirkland/COSTCO brand works really well!).  Be sure to rinse the can of black beans.   Add garlic to taste.  Garnish top with shredded cheese and avocado when serving.  Serve tortilla chips on the side.  **Try to purchase as many low-sodium items as possible to be health-conscious!

I love soup and if it is easy to make, it is a real bonus! This was sooo easy. However, I admit I made a few changes as suggested by others. I pan seared thin sliced chicken breasts in butter and olive oil and cut them up. I added cumin and chili powder to my taste (about 1 tsp cumin and 1 TBSP of chili powder. This will become a go-to soup for me!

Recipe needs seasonings of choice. Sautéed a finely chopped onion and two Cloves of  garlic. Added  a drained can  of diced tomatoes and two tablespoons  of tomato paste; simmered  until thick.  Added 14 ounces of chicken stock and one can(no water) of cream of chicken soup. Added cooked rotisserie chicken . Simmered to blend flavors.  Added corn and a can of pinto beans instead of black beans.  Heated through for about 10 minutes. Garnishes that were used individually: smoked paprika, smoked salt, ground pepper, pepper flakes and tortilla chips. We skipped the cheese to cut down on dairy.

text:
I've made this several times with some differences that go with my families preferences . I add cumin and chili powder and use kidney beans instead black beans. Also, I add a can of cream of chicken soup to make it creamier. Before I add the chicken, I sautee some onions and garlic with the chicken to give the chicken some flavor.  I top the bowls off with a dollop of sour cream, tortilla chip pieces, and shredded cheese.  In the winter I also serve this with corn muffins.  My family loves soup night! So easy and perfect for a busy week night  meal.

text:
Good starting recipe, but as others have said, you need to mess with it. 

First, use low sodium versions of everything here, if possible. There'll be plenty of salt in it. DO NOT substitute cream of chicken soup. Rather, stir in a cup of shredded monterey jack cheese when the soup is hot. Definitely add a good shake or two of garlic powder, at least a tsp. of cumin, and top with some cilantro. Chile powder is up to you, or some Chipotle Tabasco is a good add for some spice. Provide cut like wedges for squeezing when serving.

text:
I have made a very similar version of this soup for years now and each time I swear it tastes better.  It's an easy, quick and cheap family meal.  However, I use a jar of salsa instead of the Rotel and it just seems to add a little extra flavor.  I have used both canned and fresh chicken and I like the fresh chicken better, but that is a personal preference.  When using fresh I do not add any chicken broth as I just use what I boiled the chicken in.  Add some sour cream, cheese and tortilla chips and OH MY it's a great meal.

text:
After adopting many of the suggestions in previou reviews I cooked 2 medium chicken breast in the chicken broth. Once cooked I strained and reserved the broth into a glass 4 c. measuring cup. After sauteing onion and garlic for about 3 minutes I stiirred in  cumin, chili powder briefly. I added the broth, canned black beans, sliced black olives, the tomato/chlies, corn,  juice from half of a lime and chopped cilantro. After simmering for about 10 minutes I added the cooked chicken, coarsley shredded. Simmer another 5 minutes.  Garnishes of sour cream, avacado,
cilantro and lime to choose from in addition to  cheese quesadillas on the side. Thanks to everyone for the original recipe and suggestions!

city:

country:

text:
This soup comes together so quckly with things I nearly always have in the pantry.  Here is what I do differently:  I start by sautéeing onion and garlic in oil or bacon grease, then add the ingredients to the pot.  I add a can of kidney beans in addition to the black beans, add about two tablespoons of tomato paste (I use the kind in the tube), ground oregano, ground chipotle pepper, ground cumin, salt, pepper and a bay leaf.  I fry tortilla strips while it's simmering and then garnish with the chips and a dollop of sour cream.  Sometimes I get fancy and add cilantro and diced red onion for garnish.

text:
Made it vegan and it was delicious.   Replace chicken broth with vegetable broth or stock.  Add beans & vegetables.  Replace chicken with mushrooms & avocado, but do not add directly to the broth.  Lightly sauté thick sliced baby bella mushrooms and place several in the bottom of individual soup bowls.  Add several slices of avocado.  Ladle warmed soup into bowl.  Enjoy this variation OR make as written in the original recipe.  We thoroughly enjoy both!

My 4 year old eats 2 or more bowls.

text:
This recipe turned out great in a slow cooker! I doubled the recipe and replaced one can of broth with a can of cream of chicken soup. Then I added all of the ingredients (minus the canned tomatoes) plus a diced red bell pepper, diced red onion, minced jalapeño, chile powder, fresh chopped cilantro, juice from one lime, and raw chicken breasts. I let it cook on low for about 5 hours and then took the chicken breasts out and shredded them. I returned it to the crock pot, added the tomatoes, and it was a huge hit! A perfect amount of spice.

Mine turned out great, made some adjustments to the recipe for sure but in the end it was great, quick, and easy. 
I used 2 cans of rotel, or diced tomatoes, added another can of beans, I believe they were pinto beans, added salt, pepper, lots of lime juice, cumin, and several other spices. Used 1 can of chicken broth, and instead of canned chicken I chopped up 1.5 lbs of chicken and cooked it on the stove top in a pan, added real garlic, salt, pepper, etc to this chicken. Put it all together and it was great!

text:
I finally made something my husband adores!  He's a better cook so I don't cook often, but he loved this one,  with changes.  My changes:  I used creamed corn and cream of chicken,  along with chicken stock.  I don't know why people added their own spices when you can just add a taco seasoning packet.  That's all it needs.  The chilies in the Rotel gave it enough spice for me,  but some folks who don't like spice will want to use the Rotel without chilies.

Display Name:
Jamie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am only giving it 4 stars because I did make some changes.  Based on the reviews of others, I used 1 can broth and 1 can soup, which gave it a really nice consistency.  I also added some fresh cilantro, minced garlic,cumin, chili powder, chipotle powder, cayenne pepper and lime juice.  I didn't measure any of them, just did it to taste.  I also added brown rice to it.  I let the soup cook on low on the stove for quite a few hours and then added the rice in about 30 minutes before eating.  I didn't have any tortilla chips, but I wish I did, the salty crunch would have made it perfect.  So, as a *BASE* recipe, I do give this a 5, but because I had to make so many changes, I could only give it a 4.

***ETA - I used fresh, shredded chicken instead of canned, and I ended up adding another can of broth because the rice sucked up so much moisture.

text:
I added cilantro, cumin, fresh garlic, and a little chipotle chili powder.  It lacked depth and I didn't have any cream of chicken soup so I made a roux and added that.  I took 5 Tb. butter and melted it.  To the melted butter I added 5 Tb flour and stirred it well.  I then added 1 can of green enchilada sauce to the roux and stirred until blended and thicken.  I added the blended roux to the soup and it's marvelous!

userID:
1668572
Display Name:
Julie Souza Bradley Lilly
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
102
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3733423.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As others have said, this soup needs some doctoring.  I have been making my version of this soup for about 15 years.  Once doctored it is a fantastic 5 stars!  I replace one of the cans of broth with condensed cream of chicken soup.  I add about 2/3'rds of a packet of taco seasoning (more or less to your taste) and use rotisserie chicken in replacement for the canned chicken.  I also replace the canned corn with a can of mexicorn.  I don't drain anything.  I empty the entire can into the pot, add as much shredded rotisserie chicken as I desire, and heat it through.  I serve it over thick, crunchy tortilla chips (such as Mission brand chips), then top with grated cheese, a dollop of sour cream and sliced black olives and/or avocado, if desired.  Awesome!  If I double the recipe for a larger group, I replace one of the cans of black beans with dark red kidney beans.  I keep all of the canned ingredients and chips as staples in my pantry.  I also keep sour cream in the fridge and a shredded rotisserie chicken in a Zip lock bag in my freezer.  I can throw together an amazing meal that tastes like I cooked all day in just 20 minutes!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a quick and easy recipe, as promised. Like others, I made changes. I drained the corn, beans and tomatoes. Couldn't get the tomatoes with green chiles, so substituted with green peppers and onions added. I added about ½ tbs of cumin and garlic powder and 1 heaping tbs of chili powder. A little salt and pepper as well. I chopped up some jarred jalapeños, but next time I might make sure I don't put in quite as many, or don't put the seeds in -- the family thought it was a bit too spicy. I didn't have any cream of chicken soup, so didn't add it. Didn't add any cheese. Cut up some flat bread with a pizza wheel, as suggested, making tortilla "sticks."  I fried some diced chicken in garlic butter and added it to the soup. Simmered on low for too short a time, but we were hungry! Anyway, my daughter ate it up and the DH had seconds. A winner for us! Thanks for the recipe!

This is a good basic recipe to add on to or adjust. I usually use a rotisserie chicken and fresh tomatoes, but stick with the canned black beans, corn, and chilies- Or leave out the chilies completely. I then add more seasonings like a previous reviewer said to do- cumin, chili powder, a little cayenne, salt, pepper, etc. Top it with tortilla chips, cheese, and sour cream. It's a simple and quick recipe for week nights.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Granted, as written the soup lacks some things, hence my 4-star rating. 

This is what I did... rinsed the beans but added the Rotel and the corn including the water from the cans.  I also added 1 chicken breast half, 1 TBS of chili powder and 1 tsp of cumin along with 1/2 C of minced onion, 3 cloves of minced garlic (onion and garlic were sautéed before adding, 1 TBS chopped cilantro and 1 tsp of Mexican oregano.   After the cooking time of 15 or so minutes I shredded the chicken and returned to the pot.  I garnished with tortillas, cheese, and fresh cilantro.  Not watery, just good.  Also if you desire some creaminess add a dollop of sour cream to your bowl.  A 300% improvement for 5 minutes more of prep time... well worth it.

text:
YES!!! Thanks Terryn for a great recipe.  Like others, I tweaked to our taste.  Exchanged one can of broth for a can of fat free cream of chicken soup. Exchanged black beans for pinto beans - thats what I had on hand. Started with diced onions, celery, and green bell pepper sauteed til soft in EVOO (about a cup total of the mirepoix).  Had two huge cooked chicken breasts in fridge, so diced those. Thanks to others, I topped with monterey jack cheese, sour cream, and avocado. Also had limes - we love those - And made some Mexican corn bread.
Quick, Easy and oh so creamy good. Look forward to a bowl (only one leftover!) for lunch tomorrow. Thanks again, Terryn.

text:
Great base to start with.  Like others to reduce the salt I use rotisserie chicken, frozen corn, rinse my beans and add some more spice.  Instead of adding a can of condensed soup I simply add some cream. Canned soup has lots of sodium, so this is one more thing to keep that down. Sometimes I'll throw in some extras like olives or green chilis. I know this is a lot of changes, but I never follow a recipe verbatim.  Make it your own!

Display Name:
Karla Zaar

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4338890.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe!  I doctored this a bit...I combined the listed ingredients, along with with extra roasted chicken breast (leftover from fried chicken), a jar of roasted red peppers (chopped), some chopped jalepenos from a jar,sauteed minced onion, and one can of cream of chicken soup in place of one can of broth.  I did rinse the beans to keep from discoloring the broth.  I also added some chili powder, cumin, paprika, onion powder, and garlic powder.  I combined the ingredients the night before in a saucepan but did not heat...simply put in the fridge for the flavors to marry.  Heated the next day for about 30 minutes.  Garnished with fresh avocado and toasted corn tortilla slivers.  Thanks!!
Review:

userID:
4221967
Display Name:
Koneko

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/372700.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's a good base recipe but I like more kick and dimensions of flavor so I replaced the canned chicken with 2 chicken breast that I cooked in the crockpot on high with a fajita seasoning and chicken broth (about 1 cup) to keep it from burning.  Then I shredded the chicken when it was done (about 1-2 hours depending on if you use whole breasts or chop them up a bit first.  The whole are easier to shred).  I then added all the other ingredients to the same crockpot and let it cook for another hour or so.  I like to use seasoned black beans and corn with peppers if I have them on hand in place of the plain ones.  Then I top it with fresh cilantro and toasted tortilla strips I baked up in the oven, and a little cheddar.

text:
This was the easiest soup I ever made, and as others posted it was a base it did need a few things, first I don’t care for canned veggies, so I used frozen corn, peas and a few black beans I happen to have in the freezer. I shopped at Costco and bought the rotisserie chicken and shredded some of the meat to use in the soup. It was perfect… I also seasoned it with cumin, seasoned pepper and salt.  You can use any veggies you like in this soup there’s no wrong way of doing it. I topped it with corn tortilla strips, shredded cheese and avocado. 
It was fast and easy… Thanks for sharing……..

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Recipe was very good.  Very similar to a chicken taco.  I used one can cream of chicken, on can chicen stock, and made a cup of chicken stock from bullion.  I boiled one 1/3 cup onion in the bullion before adding it to the recipe.  I cut the chili powder in half since my wife does not like foods too spicy.  I would have loved the 2 tsp.  I added 1/3 cup sour cream to the recipe to add a little flavor and thickening.  Also I boiled a couple breasts and shredded them instead of using the canned chicken.  Will try adding a little red pepper and minced garlic next time, and probably the extra tsp of chili powder.  The whole family thought it was great.

text:
Notice this has over a thousand reviews.  I make it constantly.  I always add chopped garlic and cilantro.  I have tried various chicken instead of the can, but best are supermarket cooked chicken or chicken breast cut up.  Whole raw chicken is not worth the trouble. I love it and you do not need additional seasoning other than the garlic and the cilantro unless you like to add a little hot sauce.  You can at the end add grated cheddar cheese on top and a teaspoon of sour cream in each bowl.

text:
My boyfriend and I LOVE this. Of course I doctored it up. First I sauteed about 2 cups of chopped onions and green peppers in olive oil, added a teaspoon and a half of ground cumin, cooked that a bit, then added the chicken broth, canned tomatoes, the drained corn, 2 cans of drained and rinsed black beans, the chicken (2 large breasts), AND, to give it a rich and creamy broth, I melted in 8 ounces of cream cheese. Perfecto! Served with tortilla chips. YUM!

This my all-time favorite website exactly because of recipes like this!  EASY and fast, and my kids (fussy teenagers!) really liked it!  I threw it together after work on a chilly day and it was perfect.  I made it exactly as the recipe called for, but used a slotted spoon when serving in order to drain all the juice. I added black olives (my family loves them) but otherwise no changes.  Next time I plan to add the cream soup instead of one of the broths in order to thicken it up, but it was outstanding.  Will definitely make it again and again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really enjoyed this. I made it essentially the same as posted, but followed several others' recommended changes:
* Sub 1 can cream of chicken for 1 can of the broth (I used CoC w/Herbs).
* Rinse black beans very well.
* Don't drain can of chicken (I used a large can because I like a lot of meat, but you can use large or small).
* Don't drain can of Rotel tomatoes.
* Serve with fresh avocado chunks and sour cream.
* Season w/ cumin, garlic powder, onion powder, cilantro, and pepper.
* Bring to low boil, then simmer for 60 min.  Enjoy!!

country:
None
text:
Six Can Chicken Tortilla Soup Haiku: "Fool-proof recipe. Yea, yea, I added stuff too. (Or it'd be too bland.)" Can't argue w/ the ease of just opening 6 cans, but as w/ many of the reviews, I had to liven this up w/ some seasoning. But first off, I'm not a snob about canned chicken - the Kirkland chicken from Costco is outstanding, so I used everything the recipe called for. (Altho, my corn was the Mexi-type w/ bits of colored bell pepper in it.) I sauteed garlic, onion, and celery in a little butter and tossed that in the crockpot, along w/ cumin and oregano. Served w/ cheese, broken up tortilla chips, and cilantro - this soup completely wow'ed the friends I'd had over to dinner, who couldn't believe how easy it was to make.

text:
This is a great Base to your soup. I followed the reviews and used one can cream of chicken soup one can broth. I added green onions, carrots (I just had a lot in the fridge), crushed red peppers, black pepper, and about 2 tbs of garlic powder and onion powder. I also used fresh turkey instead of canned chicken, I had alot of that left over from Thanksgiving. The soup was a big hit. I was looking forward to having leftovers to bring to work for lunch... it didn't last that long at my house. I had people peeking in my crock pot looking for more! Experiment and make this recipe your own! Fantastic, I'm making it again next week!

text:
I had a lot of pulled pork left over from a party so decided to use it instead of the chicken. I followed another rater's comments but made it by the instructions first.  It was good but not great. I used fresh medium salsa instead of canned tomatoes and frozen corn.  I then added 1tsp. each of chilli powder and cumin which was a big improvement.  I then added 2 more cups of broth and the cream of chicken soup.  It watered down the flavour too much so I had to add another 1/2 tsp. each of the spices, more salsa and meat.  It was very good, but I think next time I'll substitute plain yogurt or low fat sour cream a half cup at a time to taste instead of the soup to cut fat and calories.  Very good in the end and great starting recipe.

text:
So, I usually try the recipe as it is written before I make changes, but this time, I took in the reviews and made the following changes.  I used 2 cans of cream of chicken soup and filled one can again with chicken broth (not condensed). I rinced the black beans.  I added spices to taste (garlic, cumin, chili powder, pepper).  I wish I had changed out the can chicken for real chicken, but the soup tasted great.  I also broke up the nachos on top of the cheese instead of putting them on the bottom of the bowl.  I did not like them all mushy from the soup.  This was a super easy soup to make and the whole family enjoyed it.

text:
I took mixed readers reviews and changed the following: added 2 cans of cream of chicken soup on 1 14oz can of the chicken broth. I also rinsed the beans and added cumin powder; I didn't add the chili powder until my kids had their servings. For the chicken, i boiled 3 whole boneless, skinless chicken breast in a separate pan of water until done, then peeled meat right off and added it to the soup. (Cook the chicken first).  I followed all other ingredients exactly.  I placed cut up tortilla chips on top of each bowl of soup, along with shredded cheddar cheese. Delicious recipe!

country:

text:
This soup is SO GOOD and SO EASY! Per the suggestions of other reviewers, I used shredded rotisserie chicken and added one can of condensed cream of chicken soup. Also added a sprinkle of garlic salt and paprika. Rinsed the black beans before adding in as well (apparently, without rinsing the beans, the soup can look "muddy"). I didn't even bother with toppings like sour cream, avocado, etc., although I'm sure it would be great with those additions as well. Delish!

text:
This was really good for two reasons. 1. I needed a fast meal and this really delivered. It took maybe 15 minutes total. 2. If you keep a stocked pantry you are always going to have most of these ingredients on hand. (I always have chicken stock!)

I doctored this up with chipotle hot sauce and for toppings we used diced avocado, tortilla chips, and shredded monterrey jack. Really made it feel homemade.

text:
Easy to make, great taste and you can vary the degree of "hotness." 
Suggest using chicken broth versus chicken stock.  The broth is hearty, thicker and enhances the flavor, while the stock is thinner and tends to water down the flavor.

text:
I thought this soup was amazing!  I did tweak a couple things from reading the reviews... I doubled the amount of broth( I made mine from chicken bouillon, 32oz water to 4tsp bouillon), used 2 cans of cream of chicken, added zucchini, and a fresh tomato along with the canned diced... I used 3 big chicken breasts and boiled them in salted water... shredded when cooled and added to the pot... was an amazing, chunky chicken soup that my family loved... made homemade fried tortilla strips and topped with cilantro, squeeze of lime, and avocado!  Will be making this many more times!!!

text:
I've been using the recipe for years!  We make it to go along with tacos.  I don't use beans, however, as it wasn't part of the recipe I used, I also use medium salsa instead of the tomatoes and chili's.  I find that it has better spice.  I add a little lime juice and some garlic powder, too.  And I typically use frozen corn instead of canned because it's more convenient for me.  We serve it with shredded cheddar on top and crumbled up tortilla chips.  It's a hit with the adults and the kids and makes enough for leftovers, too.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
**Great and easy!  We used this recipe for a nice romantic night.  **I used two whole chicken breasts and grilled them a bit before cutting them up and tossing them in.  We had more fresh ingredients at the time than canned so we emptied the can of beans and used the empty can to measure out what we needed.  **I boiled a leftover rotisserie chicken carcass with some garlic and onions and used the stock for this recipe (the rotisserie ones you get from the store makes excellent stock and is a good use to the bones!)    **We used fresh tomatoes and two chopped serrano chillies.  I also added in 4-5 cloves of garlic and almost a half of a brown onion thinly sliced.  We also defrosted some frozen corn and tossed that in.    We let the whole thing simmer for a while until the ingredients melded together and seasoned to taste.    Also we did not have tortilla chips so we took some corn tortilla and cut it into strips and chunks and browned until crunchy with a bit of olive oil. Will make this very easy dish again!

text:
I loved this recipe and so did my husband!  I too made some changes, but not many.   I felt 2 cans of broth made it too watered down, so left it to one.  To thicken it up even MORE, I added a 1/2 packet of Spanish rice (Knorr I think) and covered it a bit to cook the rice through.  This gave it awesome taste!  Also can throw in a dash of cumin and chili powder.  Throw this version over crushed tortilla chips and top with grated cheese and sour cream.  YUMMY!

text:
Yay!  Something easy and healthy to add to my repertoire.  I made a double batch using all the helpful hints from previous reviewers - rotisserie chicken, Rotel Tomatoes with Lime Juice and Cilantro (kinda spicy-yum), half broth/half cream of chicken soup with can of water, 1 tsp Cumin (could use 2 tsp), frozen corn (instead of canned).  I used one can black beans and one can black eyed-peas (tasty). You could use pinto or kidney beans too.  It turned out delish.  No other spices or seasoning needed.  For my double batch I added 1/4 cup of rice.  It thickened up nicely by the time it was done.  My family loved it. It was very filling and satisfying.

This was a great base recipe! I used regular (non-condensed) chicken broth, replaced one can of broth with cream of chicken soup, browned and cubed regular chicken. Display Name:
Krystal Lamm

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6986824.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With the weather getting chilly, and my husband coming down with a cold, I decided to make a tortilla soup. I like this recipe because I favor a clear, thin broth as opposed to the versions with enchilada sauce or cream.  This soup was so yummy after my "alterations" - I used frozen chicken breasts that I boiled with some diced onion in the chicken stock and then shredded. I used three cans of stock instead of two. I always rinse my black beans (which wasn't noted on the recipe). The soup was a bit bland, so I added a hefty amount of taco seasoning - but you could just add chili powder, cumin, salt, pepper and garlic powder to taste.  I topped with cilantro and a dash of lime. Wonderful!

text:
FANTASTIC! I broiled two boneless chicken breasts, used Del Monte Zesty Chili Style diced tomatoes (I was out of RoTel), used 1 can chicken broth and 1 can cream of chicken, added black olives, cumin, garlic powder, chili powder and green chilis, omitted the corn since I didn't have it on-hand. Threw it in the crockpot for several hours and served it with cornbread. My husband and I both went nutso over it! Great recipe and so easy to throw together! Will be a staple in our home!

text:
I've been making something almost identical to this for years.  I always keep the ingredients in my pantry for a quick, last-minute meal.  The slight difference of my recipe is that I don't use any chicken broth (for liquid, we don't drain the other cans), we use salsa instead of diced tomatoes, and we add a can of refried beans.  The refried beans help thicken the soup and make it taste rich. We love this soup!  And I'm making it right now as I type!!

country:

text:
This is one of the best ideas I've come across in awhile! I usually make chicken tortilla soup from scratch, making my own broth and everything from the whole chicken, but this was JUST as good and in 1/4 of the time! Of course I made changes...I sauteed some onions in olive oil for a few minutes in the bottom of my pot. The oil really helps bring out the flavor of the spices. I used a can of chicken broth, can of water, and a can of Cream of Chicken as recommended by others. I was liberal with the Comino and Chili Powder. I also added a cup of rice to the mix at the end to soak up the extra water. Added in some cilantro to each bowl and shredded some Monterrey Jack cheese in while hot. DELICIOUS!

text:
Loved it!  Easy and very flavorful.  The only change I made was to the chicken. I boiled i package of chicken thighs in chicken broth and a packet of chicken taco seasoning for ninety minutes, then shredded the chicken. I added the remaining ingredients to the chicken broth along with the shredded chicken and brought to a boil. I also added some diced jalapenos for a kick! Served over the tortilla chips with Sour cream and a pinch of cilantro.  Huge Hit!  This is my new favorite

text:
Good base recipe. I made it my own by adding a can of kidney beans along with the can of black beans just for extra flavor. Make sure you drain everything and rinse the beans well. Instead of the tomatoes with green chiles, I used a can of diced tomatoes and a separate 7 oz. can of the diced green chiles. Like other reviewers had suggested, I added some ground cumin, chili powder, black pepper and garlic salt to taste. I also used two fresh chicken breasts that I diced and cooked first. Canned chicken just did not sound appealing to me. Then I shredded some pepperjack cheese on top. Yum yum!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/63329.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! It's one of my favorite standbys. I use one of the large cans of regular chicken broth and one can of condensed cream of chicken soup. I add those first and mix them up well before adding the other ingredients, or else I get globs of the cream of chicken that won't dissolve. This seems to give me the right ratio of soup to solids and adds a little bit of creamy taste without being too heavy. I also add a little garlic powder, onion salt, and some dried parsley flakes. One tip: be sure to rinse the black beans well or they will turn the whole thing a disgusting blue/gray color! (It still tastes good, though.) I skip the tortilla chips and serve with cornbread muffins.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is one of the rare times when canned ingredients make a delicious, "can't tell it's not from scratch" dish.  Your guests will be asking for the recipe and you'll hate to tell them how incredibly simple it is!  The recipe is a great base, but I made a few changes.  I reduced the chicken broth to 16 oz. and added one can of Campbell's Southwest style pepper jack soup.  I also used a store bought roasted chicken instead of canned chicken.  Although I drained the black beans, the soup still had an unappealing grayish cast, so I added about 8 oz. tomato sauce.  This changed the color of the soup to a creamy red which was more appealing.  Serve with tortilla chips, shredded cheese, avocado, salsa and sour cream on the side so your guests can add to their liking.

text:
This was very good.  I added some ingredients for fear of it being "bland"...Velveeta and some leftover cream of chicken soup I had in the fridge to make it a little creamier.  Be sure and rinse the black beans (it affects the color of the soup).  I also added some Southwest seasoning to the chicken (I cooked chicken breasts. I did NOT use canned) as well as a wee bit to the soup too.  I also added garlic and onion powder and Hasa Marina (corn flour) to give it more of a "Tortilla" taste.  Shredded cheese and chips on the top is a MUST.  I even put a dallop of sour cream on the top too.  I have a copycat recipe for Chili's Chicken Enchilada soup and I like it better, but this one was very fast and easy.  I would make it again.  It was a hit!  Thanks for posting :)

text:
I love this recipe but only WITH some of the previous reviewers' suggestions. 
1: Chunk chicken sounds UNnatural. I buy flat chicken strips and fry on the stve with a bit of butter or oil. Then I chop into small bits and add.
2. DRAIN thhe black beans and strain them under water!
3. Get creative! Add spices and other ingredients and really make this your own. My husband loves this soup!

This soup is really easy!!!! And with just a few changes it was perfect for my family. I did not subtract anything, I just added 1/2 a diced onion, 1 can condensed cream of chicken soup, 1 tablespoon cumin, some salt and pepper. I finished the soup in less than 20 minutes! I think next time I will add more chicken and beans, to make it more like a chili.

text:
I wasn't sure how good the soup would be, I mean six cans and you have chicken tortilla? But I must say it was pretty tasty. Based on previous reviewers I used 1 can chicken broth and 1 can cream of chicken soup. I also added in cooked white rice and cooked it in a crock pot for 6 hours. I sliced up avacado and seasoned it with lime juice. Then crumbled tortillas chips over it. Very good! Don't let the brownish color scare you though, it is just from the black beans, which I suggest draining if it will bother you. Overall, I will make again when I am in a pinch for a quick and tasty meal. Thanks!

None
text:
Very, very good for a such an easy soup!  I added lots of fresh cilantro, cumin, and chili powder.  Also, rinse the chicken and black beans well before adding to the soup.  The first time I made it, I just dumped it all in and the soup was an ugly brownish gray color.  But the taste was still great.  I use frozen or fresh corn because I don't really like canned corn.  I was very pleasantly suprised to find that canned chicken isn't too bad (I've never used it before), although I still prefer to poach a chicken breast and cube the meat instead.  I'll probably keep these ingredients on hand all the time now!

what a joy this was! i doubled the recipe and subbed one can of corn for creamed corn and also one can of chicken stock was replaced with cream of chicken soup (with one can of water). i added a can of diced green chili's and some frozen veggies. topped with cheese and sour cream. also, i fried up some strips of corn tortillas in a little olive oil until crispy and golden and put them in the bottom of a soup mug and topped with the soup.
this really is absolutely delicious! i did spice with a little cumin and dried basil and chili powder. thanks for the recipe!

I made this last night and I have to say it was really tasty and quick to make.  I did look at how some people tweaked the recipe in the reviews to add some flavor, and so I tried a bit of my own.  First I sauteed some chopped onions and minced garlic before adding the canned ingredients.  I rinsed the beans thoroughly like many suggested.  I added a little bit of dried oregano and some chili powder and a little bit of mild salsa.  I also used chiken stock instead of broth. I baked some tortillas in the oven and broke them up into pieces to put at the bottom of the bowls.  Yum.

text:
This was really great.  Quick & easy too.  I only had a few minutes before out of town family arrived for lunch.  I used boneless chicken strips and browned them in the pot before adding the cans. Then I substituted a can of cream of chicken soup for one of the cans of broth. Also used the mild tomatoes with green chilies.  It was spicer than I expected.  No need to add any seasoning.  Everyone ate it--even my VERY picky father-in-law.
